question.text: What is pinocytosis?

options.label: D.
options.text: Shriveling of cells in hypertonic solutions

explanation.concept_text: Endocytosis is a process by which cells absorb extracellular material by engulfing it within the cell membrane. Endocytosis encompasses three different types of active transport: phagocytosis, pinocytosis, and receptor-mediated endocytosis. Phagocytosis is the process by which an undissolved material in solid form enters the cell. The cell engulfs the material by wrapping its plasma membrane outward around the substance, creating a vesicle. Phagocytosis is used by certain immune cells (phagocytes) to bring in pathogens. Once the phagocytes take up pathogens via phagocytosis, they use the digestive enzymes from lysosomes to destroy the ingested material. Pinocytosis is the process by which the plasma membrane invaginates around a dissolved material in liquid form. During pinocytosis, the membrane pinches inwards to non-selectively incorporate extracellular fluid and substances dissolved in the liquid. Receptor-mediated endocytosis is a form of endocytosis that is triggered by extracellular molecules binding to receptors on the cell membrane. Receptor-mediated endocytosis is often facilitated by clathrin. Once extracellular molecules bind to membrane receptors, they signal clathrin proteins to attach to the membrane and pull inward, eventually allowing the cell to form a clathrin-coated vesicle. These three types of endocytosis are illustrated in the image below. Since pinocytosis can be described as the cellular intake of dissolved solutes, Option E. Cellular intake of dissolved solutes is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Post-translational modification of proteins – This option is incorrect because pinocytosis is the cellular intake of dissolved solutes, and the process does not involve any kind of protein modification. The post-translational modification of proteins is a process of changing proteins after they have been synthesized by ribosomes. Post-translational modifications include the addition of sugars, lipids, and phosphate groups to amino acids. The rough endoplasmic reticulum (rough ER) and the Golgi apparatus are organelles responsible for the post-translational modifications of proteins. Option B. Removal of introns after transcription – This option is incorrect because pinocytosis is the cellular intake of dissolved solutes, and the process does not involve the removal of introns. The removal of introns after transcription is called RNA splicing. During the process of RNA splicing, spliceosomes delete introns and connect exons. Introns are non-coding sections of a RNA transcript, whereas exons are sections of RNA that code for proteins. Since prokaryotes lack introns, RNA splicing only occurs in eukaryotes. Option C. Clathrin-facilitated intake of solids – This option is incorrect because pinocytosis does not engulf extracellular material that are in solid form; it instead engulfs extracellular material that are in liquid form (dissolved solutes). Pinocytosis is also not facilitated by clathrin. Clathrin are proteins that coat intracellular vesicles used to transport cargo within the cell. Clathrin-dependent endocytosis relies on clathrin for selective endocytosis of extracellular material. Once extracellular molecules bind to membrane receptors, they signal clathrin molecules to attach to the membrane and pull inward. This folding of the membrane allows the formation of clathrin-coated intracellular vesicles. Hence, clathrin-dependent endocytosis is a type of receptor-mediated endocytosis. Option D. Shriveling of cells in hypertonic solutions – This option is incorrect because pinocytosis is the cellular intake of dissolved solutes, and it does not involve the shriveling of cells (or any other change in cell turgidity). The shriveling of cells occurs in hypertonic solutions and is a result of osmosis. Osmosis is the movement of water across a semipermeable membrane from a region of low solute concentration to a region of high solute concentration. When a cell is placed in a hypertonic solution (higher solute concentration outside the cell), water leaves the cell, causing the cell to shrivel. On the other hand, when a cell is placed in a hypotonic solution (lower solute concentration outside the cell), water enters the cell, causing the cell to swell.

question.text: Which germ layer forms most of the peripheral nervous system?

explanation.concept_text: Gastrulation is a critical phase in early embryonic development during which the single-layered blastula is reorganized into a multilayered structure known as the gastrula. This process begins with the formation of the primitive streak , a narrow groove on the surface of the early embryo. The cells of the epiblast, which is the upper layer of the blastula, move toward the primitive streak, migrate inward and downward, and differentiate into the three primary germ layers. These three germ layers are listed from superficial to deep as follows: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Once these three germ layers are formed, the embryo is officially considered a gastrula . Each of the three germ layers will differentiate and develop into various structures and systems of the body. The ectoderm will differentiate to form the nervous system (brain and spinal cord), integument (epidermis, hair, epithelium of the nose, mouth, and anal canal), sensory structures of the eyes, ears, and nose, as well as the adrenal medulla. Neural crest cells of the ectoderm will also form the teeth, jaws, bones, muscles of the skull, pigment cells in the skin, and nerve tissue. The mesoderm will give rise to the musculoskeletal system, the circulatory system, the excretory system, the gonads, portions of the digestive and respiratory system, the notochord, the kidney, the dermis of the skin, and the adrenal cortex. The endoderm will give rise to the epithelial lining of the digestive and respiratory tract, portions of the liver, the pancreas, the gallbladder, the thyroid and parathyroid, the thymus, and the lining of the urinary bladder. Since both the central and peripheral nervous systems are formed by the ectoderm, Option A is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Endoderm – This option is incorrect because the endoderm gives rise to epithelial linings of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, the urinary bladder and urethra, the liver, the pancreas, the thyroid and parathyroid, and the thymus. The ectoderm gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous system, not the endoderm. Option C. Mesoderm – This option is incorrect because the mesoderm gives rise to the musculoskeletal system, the circulatory system, the excretory system, the gonads, connective tissue, portions of the digestive and respiratory system, the notochord, the kidney, the dermis of the skin, and the adrenal cortex. The ectoderm gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous system, not the mesoderm. Option D. Zygote – This option is incorrect because the zygote is not an embryonic germ layer. The zygote is a diploid, fertilized egg cell that results from the fusion of the sperm and ovum nuclei. The zygote undergoes cleavage (rapid cell divisions) to form the morula. The morula, a solid ball of cells, undergoes more cleavage to form the blastula. The blastula, a hollow sphere of cells, then undergoes gastrulation to form the gastrula. The gastrula is a multicellular embryo that consists of three embryonic germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. These germ layers later give rise to their subsequent tissues. Option E. Epidermis – This option is incorrect because the epidermis is not an embryonic germ layer. The epidermis is the most superficial, avascular layer of skin that relies on the dermis for oxygen and nutrients. The cells of the epidermis help waterproof the skin, function in touch sensation, and contain skin pigment called melanin. The epidermis is divided into five layers: stratum corneum, stratum lucidum, stratum granulosum, stratum spinous, and stratum basale. The epidermis is formed from the ectoderm. The ectoderm also gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous system. While the epidermis shares a common embryonic layer of origin with the peripheral nervous system, it is a completely separate structure.

question.text: The movement of water from areas of low solute concentration to high solute concentration across a semipermeable membrane is defined as __________.

explanation.concept_text: Osmosis is the movement of water across a semipermeable membrane from a region of low solute concentration to a region of high solute concentration. Osmosis is responsible for “balancing out” solute concentrations on either side of the membrane. By moving water out of the region of low solute concentration, the region becomes more concentrated, resulting in an increased solute concentration. Similarly, by moving water into the region of high solute concentration, the region becomes more dilute, resulting in a decreased solute concentration. Osmosis is an example of passive transport as it does not require ATP. Hypertonic solutions have a higher solute concentration than the cells placed inside them. When a cell is placed in a hypertonic solution, water leaves the cell because water moves from a region of lower solute concentration (the cell) to a region of higher solute concentration (the hypertonic solution). When an animal cell is placed in a hypertonic solution and water leaves the cell, the cell sh rivel s . When a plant cell is placed in a hypertonic solution and water leaves the cell, pl asmolysis occurs. Plasmolysis refers to the shrinkage of the cytoplasm of a plant cell, away from its cell wall. On the other hand, hypotonic solutions have a lower solute concentration than the cells placed inside them. When a cell is placed in a hypotonic solution, water enters the cell because water again moves from a region of lower concentration (the hypotonic solution) to a region of higher solute concentration (the cell). When an animal cell is placed in a hypotonic solution and water enters the cell, the cell swells up and can eventually lyse (burst). When a plant cell is placed in a hypotonic solution, it becomes turgid . A turgid plant cell is a plant cell that has swollen up due to the increased amount of water. Plant cells, however, do not undergo lysis because they have a rigid cell wall that prevents them from bursting. Isotonic solutions have the same solute concentration as the cells placed inside them; hence, there is no net movement of water. The images below illustrate osmosis in animal and plant cells under varying conditions. Since osmosis is the movement of water from areas of low concentration to high concentration, Option D. Osmosis is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Active transport – This option is incorrect because while active transport refers to the movement of molecules against their concentration gradient, the question is asking for a process that involves the movement of water. Furthermore, active transport requires energy, while the movement of water (osmosis) does not. Active transport uses energy (ATP) to move solutes like small ions, amino acids, and monosaccharides across the cell membrane against their concentration gradient. Option B. Facilitated diffusion – This option is incorrect because while facilitated diffusion refers to the movement of molecules through protein channels, the question is asking for the movement of water across a semipermeable membrane–a process that does not require the use of protein channels. Facilitated diffusion is a type of passive transport in which molecules cross the cell membrane with the help of specific integral proteins called transport proteins. Unlike active transport, facilitated diffusion (as well as other types of passive transport) do not require energy. Option C. Nondisjunction – This option is incorrect because nondisjunction does not involve the movement of water across a membrane; it instead refers to the process by which one or more chromosome pairs or chromatids fail to separate during anaphase. Depending on when nondisjunction occurs, different outcomes can occur. If nondisjunction occurs in meiosis I, homologous chromosomes fail to separate. If nondisjunction occurs in mitosis or meiosis II, sister chromatids fail to separate. Nondisjunction can lead to genetic disorders including Down syndrome (trisomy 21) and Turner syndrome (monosomy X). Option E. Phagocytosis – This option is incorrect because phagocytosis does not involve the movement of water across a membrane; it instead refers to the process by which undissolved material (solid) enters a cell via engulfment. An example of phagocytosis is the activity of white blood cells (leukocytes). White blood cells engulf pathogens by wrapping their plasma membrane around the pathogen.

question.text: Identify the function of the structure indicated in the image below:

explanation.concept_text: The structure shown in the image is a sarcomere , the functional unit of a striated muscle fiber. The sarcomere is the structure responsible for muscle contraction. Sarcomeres are present in both skeletal and cardiac muscle because both of these muscle types are striated. Sarcomeres contain thick filaments ( myosin ) and thin filaments ( actin ) that slide past one another when the muscle contracts. This phenomenon is known as the sliding filament theory and is an important process to know for the test. It is crucial to remember that the individual myofilaments do not shorten in length, but rather, the sarcomere itself will shorten in length as the myofilaments increase in their overlap over one another. The sliding filament theory is relatively extensive. It is recommended that you refresh yourself on this topic if you don’t fully understand it. Below is an image that depicts the anatomy of a sarcomere. The Z-lines represent the borders of one individual sarcomere that anchors thin filaments. The M-line represents the middle of the sarcomere. The I-band is the region of the sarcomere that contains thin filaments (actin) only. The H-zone is the region of the sarcomere that contains thick filaments (myosin) only. The A-band is the area of the sarcomere where actin and myosin overlap. It is important to note that the H-zone and I-band reduce during contraction, while the A-band does not. Since the image in question shows a sarcomere and sarcomeres are the structural unit of striated muscle fibers that function in contraction, Option C is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0 CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Protein synthesis – This option is incorrect because the image in question depicts a sarcomere, the functional unit of striated muscle fibers that function in muscular contraction. Ribosomes are organelles made of rRNA that function to synthesize proteins by linking together amino acids. Amino acids form peptide bonds with one another to form proteins. This would have been the correct answer choice if the image was of the rough ER rather than skeletal muscle fibers. Option B. Lipid production – This option is incorrect because the image in question depicts a sarcomere, the functional unit of striated muscle fibers that function in muscular contraction. The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is responsible for the production of lipids and steroid hormones for export. Option D. Regulation of osmosis – This option is incorrect because the image in question depicts a sarcomere, the functional unit of striated muscle fibers that function in muscular contraction. Recall that osmosis is the passive transport of water across a semipermeable membrane from regions of low solute concentration to regions of high solute concentration. Osmosis is a process that is commonly seen across the cell membrane. Sarcomeres do not regulate osmosis. Option E. Bone resorption – This option is incorrect because the image in question depicts a sarcomere, the functional unit of striated muscle fibers that function in muscular contraction. Osteoclasts are bone cells that are responsible for bone resorption. These cells resorb the bone matrix and release the minerals back to the blood. Hence, osteoclast activity increases blood calcium levels. Recall that the parathyroid hormone (PTH) is responsible for increasing circulating calcium (Ca 2+ ) levels by increasing the proliferation and activity of osteoclasts.

question.text: Which of the following layers covers the surface of cortical bone?

explanation.concept_text: In order to answer this question, we must first differentiate cortical bone from cancellous bone. Cortical bone is much denser than cancellous bone and is characterized by its presence of osteons . Osteons are the functional unit of cortical bone, At the center of each osteon is a structure known as the Haversian canal . The Haversian canal contains nerves and blood vessels that supply bone cells with their required nutrients. Cancellous bone , also known as spongy bone, is much more flexible than cortical bone. Instead of osteons, cancellous bone contains trabeculae which contribute to strength and flexibility. Cancellous bone is also filled with red bone marrow which is the site of hemopoiesis (red blood cell development). It is also important to understand the various bone types of the skeletal system. These bone types include long bone, short bone, flat bone, sesamoid bone, and irregular bone. Each bone type contains a different relative abundance of cortical bone and cancellous bone. For example, short bones are primarily made of cancellous bones while long bones are primarily made of cortical bone. The image below helps us visualize a long bone. As we can see, cortical bone (compact bone) creates the outer layer of long bones with cancellous bone being housed within cortical bone at the metaphysis and epiphysis. Cortical bone is composed of two fibrous membranes: the periosteum and the endosteum. The periosteum is the outermost membrane that wraps itself around cortical bone. The endosteum is the innermost membrane of cortical bone and is the border between cancellous and cortical bone. Because the periosteum lines the outer surface of cortical bone, Option B. Periosteum is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Spongy bone – This option is incorrect because spongy bone does not cover the surface of cortical bone. Spongy bone, also known as cancellous bone, is a type of bone characterized by the presence of trabeculae. Spongy bone is typically encased in cortical bone and is much more flexible than cortical bone. Spongy bone contains red bone marrow which is the site of red blood cell development. Option C. Endosteum – This option is incorrect because the endosteum does not cover the surface of cortical bone. The endosteum is instead a fibrous membrane that lies between cortical and cancellous bone. The endosteum is the innermost layer of cortical bone. Option D. Epiphyseal line – This option is incorrect because the epiphyseal line does not cover the surface of cortical bone. Epiphyseal lines develop when the epiphyseal plate becomes ossified. Recall that long bone growth occurs when the hyaline cartilage of the epiphyseal plate, which is located between the epiphysis and metaphysis, grows in the direction of the metaphysis, lengthening the diaphysis. Once bone growth is complete, the epiphyseal plate will ossify and become the epiphyseal line. Option E. Compact bone – This option is incorrect because compact bone is another name for cortical bone. Since this question asks which layer covers the surface of cortical bone, we know this option cannot be correct.

question.text: Which of the following organisms belongs to the kingdom Protista?

explanation.concept_text: Protista , a kingdom of the domain Eukarya, is classified by means of locomotion and the ways in which an organism obtains energy. Plant-like protists , also known as algae-like protists, obtain energy through photosynthesis. These protists absorb light energy via photosynthetic pigments and store energy in the form of carbohydrates. Examples of plant-like protists include brown, red, and some green algae. Animal-like protists , also known as protozoa, are heterotrophs. These protists consume living cells or dead organic matter to obtain energy. Examples of animal-like protists include amoeba. Fungus-like protists resemble fungi by forming filaments and spore-bearing bodies. Examples of fungus-like protists include cellular and plasmodial slime molds. It is important to distinguish between eukaryotic algae and prokaryotic algae. Eukaryotic algae, such as brown, red and some green algae, are plant-like protists that fall under the domain Eukarya. On the other hand, prokaryotic algae are included in the domain Bacteria. Cyanobacteria is an example of prokaryotic algae. Cyanobacteria, known as blue-green algae, are photosynthetic bacteria that grow rapidly in aquatic environments. Since eukaryotic algae is an organism that belongs to the kingdom Protista, specifically the subgroup of plant-like protists, Option C. Eukaryotic algae is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Ferns – This option is incorrect because ferns belong to the kingdom Plantae, specifically the division of tracheophytes (seedless vascular plants) called pterophyta. While these plants lack seeds, they have true roots, leaves, and stems. Ferns produce clusters of sporangia (structures that produce spores). In ferns, the predominant plant form is the sporophyte. Option B. Fungi – This option is incorrect because fungi itself is its own kingdom (kingdom Fungi). Fungi are eukaryotic heterotrophs that secrete digestive enzymes onto organic matter and then absorb the products of digestion for energy. While most fungi are multicellular, there are unicellular fungi such as yeast. Fungi alternate their diploid/haploid stages, but the haploid stage generally predominates in the life cycle of most fungi. Option D. Cyanobacteria – This option is incorrect because cyanobacteria belong to the domain Bacteria, while the kingdom Protista belongs to the domain Eukarya. Cyanobacteria is a common group of bacteria that are photosynthetic. Some cyanobacteria produce nitrogen-fixing enzymes that convert nitrogen gas into ammonia (NH 3 ). Cyanobacteria are known as blue-green algae and are not related to the other eukaryotic algae groups. As primitive autotrophic prokaryotes, cyanobacteria are believed to be responsible for creating the Earth’s oxygen-rich atmosphere, as they continued to produce oxygen via the process of photosynthesis that was released into the atmosphere and gradually accumulated. Option E. Mushroom – This option is incorrect because mushrooms belong to the kingdom Fungi, specifically the fungus group called Basidiomycota. These fungi reproduce sexually by producing haploid spores. These spores undergo plasmogamy and mitosis to create a fruiting body called the basidiocarp, more commonly known as mushrooms.

question.text: Where does cyclic photophosphorylation occur?

explanation.concept_text: Photosynthesis is the process that harnesses light energy to synthesize glucose. The light-dependent reaction of photosynthesis includes non-cyclic photophosphorylation and cyclic photophosphorylation. Non-cyclic photophosphorylation takes place in the thylakoid membrane . During non-cyclic photophosphorylation, light is incorporated into electrons, causing them to be excited and lose stability. These electrons re-emit the absorbed energy, which is then reabsorbed by electrons in nearby pigment molecules. As a result, ATP and NADPH are produced. Cyclic photophosphorylation takes place in the stroma lamellae , the tubules that connect the thylakoids to one another. Cyclic photophosphorylation functions to replenish ATP for the Calvin Cycle. The Calvin Cycle , also known as the “dark” reaction, takes place in the stroma of the chloroplast. During the Calvin Cycle, 6 CO 2 molecules are fixed to ultimately synthesize glucose. This glucose is used by the mitochondria of the plant as energy. Since cyclic photophosphorylation occurs in the stroma lamellae, Option A. Stroma lamellae is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Mitochondrial matrix – This option is incorrect because cyclic photophosphorylation occurs in the stroma lamellae of the chloroplast, instead of the mitochondrial matrix. In fact, none of the photosynthetic reactions take place in the mitochondrial matrix because photosynthesis does not happen in mitochondria. Chloroplasts, instead, are the organelles that are responsible for carrying out photosynthesis. Mitochondria are responsible for making ATP and also serve as the site of fatty acid catabolism during beta-oxidation. Option C. Outer chloroplast membrane – This option is incorrect because cyclic photophosphorylation occurs in the stroma lamellae, instead of the outer chloroplast membrane. It is important to note that the thylakoid membrane is responsible for absorbing light, rather than the outer or inner chloroplast membrane. None of the photosynthetic reactions take place in the outer chloroplast membrane. Option D. Xylem – This option is incorrect because cyclic photophosphorylation occurs in the stroma lamellae, instead of the xylem. The xylem is a transport tissue in vascular plants that functions to transport water and minerals throughout the plant. There are two kinds of xylem cells: tracheids and vessel elements. Option E. Nucleus – This option is incorrect because cyclic photophosphorylation occurs in the stroma lamellae of the chloroplast, instead of the nucleus. In fact, none of the photosynthetic reactions take place in the nucleus because photosynthesis does not happen in the nucleus. Chloroplasts, instead, are the organelles that are responsible for carrying out photosynthesis. The nucleus is responsible for storing the genetic material of the cell and is the site of DNA replication and transcription in eukaryotes.

question.text: If an organism is missing a chromosome, which term is used to describe the abnormality?

explanation.concept_text: Nondisjunction is the failure of one or more homologous chromosome pairs or sister chromatids to separate properly during cell division, specifically anaphase. Depending on when nondisjunction occurs, different outcomes can occur. If nondisjunction occurs in meiosis I, homologous chromosomes fail to separate. If nondisjunction occurs in mitosis or meiosis II, sister chromatids fail to separate. The image below shows the different outcomes of nondisjunction in meiosis I and II. Aneuploidy describes a genome with extra or missing chromosomes, often caused by nondisjunction. Trisomy describes the condition in which a genome of an organism contains an extra chromosome. An example of trisomy is Down syndrome (a genetic disorder caused by trisomy 21, an extra copy of chromosome 21). Monosomy describes the condition in which a genome of an organism is missing a chromosome. An example of monosomy is Turner’s syndrome. Turner’s syndrome is a genetic disorder in which an individual only has one sex chromosome (an X chromosome), and no second copy. Since monosomy is the term used to describe a missing chromosome, Option B. Monosomy is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Trisomy – This option is incorrect because trisomy is the term used to describe an extra chromosome, instead of a missing chromosome. Trisomy describes the condition in which a genome of an organism contains an extra chromosome due to nondisjunction. An example of trisomy is Down syndrome. Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by trisomy 21, an extra copy of chromosome 21. Option C. Translocation – This option is incorrect because translocation is the term used to describe the movement of one segment of a chromosome to another chromosome. There are two types of translocation. One type of translocation occurs when two non-homologous chromosomes swap segments (for example, chromosome #1 and chromosome #12 swapping a segment of each chromosome). Another type of translocation (often referred to as just a substitution) occurs when one chromosome from a homologous pair becomes attached to another chromosome from a different pair (for example, a segment of chromosome #2 being moved to chromosome #11). Option D. Oncogene – This option is incorrect because oncogenes are mutated proto-oncogenes that result in a higher risk of cancer. Proto-oncogenes are genes involved in regulating cell growth and division. These genes positively regulate the cell cycle by allowing cells to proceed from one stage of the cell cycle to the next. When proto-oncogenes undergo mutation and become oncogenes, gene expression is modified and cell division eventually becomes unregulated. For example, the Ras gene (example of a proto-oncogene) can be mutated to become an oncogene, causing accelerated and uncontrollable cell growth and proliferation. Option E. Cleavage – This option is incorrect because cleavage is the process in which the zygote undergoes rapid cell division without any cell growth. Each cell resulting from cleavage is called a blastomere. Successive cleavage results in a solid ball of ~8 cells called the morula. The morula continues to divide into the blastula and the gastrula.

question.text: The secretion of which hormone would be expected to decrease following surgical removal of the posterior pituitary gland?

explanation.concept_text: The posterior pituitary is a gland made up of neuronal tissue that is continuous with the hypothalamus. The posterior pituitary does not produce its own hormones, but rather, stores and secretes certain hormones that are made from the hypothalamus. The primary hormones stored in the posterior pituitary are vasopressin, also known as the antidiuretic hormone (ADH), and oxytocin. Recall that vasopressin is an important hormone that decreases urination. This is important to counteract dehydration by increasing the reabsorption of water in the collecting duct and distal convoluted tubule of nephrons (recall that nephrons are the functional unit of the kidney). Reabsorption, in other words, is the body holding onto a substance rather than excreting it in urine – in this case, the body holds on to more water. This is done by increasing the number of aquaporins which are essentially water channels that accumulate on the collecting duct to allow for the movement of water back into the circulatory system. This will cause urine to become much more concentrated, the sole reason behind urine being yellow when we haven’t drunk enough water during the day. Oxytocin is the other hormone that is released from the posterior pituitary. Oxytocin is released during childbirth to increase the force of uterine contractions. Oxytocin also stimulates the contraction of breast tissue to assist in milk ejection during breastfeeding. In addition to its function in childbirth and breastfeeding, oxytocin is also known to enhance maternal behavior. As we can see from the information above, the surgical removal of the posterior pituitary would lead to a decrease in the levels of both hormones that it secretes: vasopressin (ADH) and oxytocin. Therefore, Option C. Vasopressin is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. FSH – This option is incorrect because follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) is released from the anterior pituitary, not the posterior pituitary. All hormones released from the anterior pituitary, including FSH, are peptide hormones. In females, FSH stimulates the ovarian follicles, causing them to release estrogen. In males, FSH stimulates the testes to start spermatogenesis, the production of mature sperm. Option B. LH – This option is incorrect because luteinizing hormone (LH) is released from the anterior pituitary, not the posterior pituitary. All hormones released from the anterior pituitary, including LH, are peptide hormones. In females, a surge of LH is responsible for the commencement of ovulation during the menstrual cycle. Ovulation is the process in which an egg is released from the ovaries. LH also allows the formation of the corpus luteum in females. LH is also responsible for stimulating the testes in males to release testosterone. Option D. hGH – This option is incorrect because human growth hormone (hGH) is released from the anterior pituitary, not the posterior pituitary. All hormones released from the anterior pituitary, including hGH, are peptide hormones. Recall that hGH, also known as somatotropin, is responsible for the growth and development of muscles and bones. hGH stimulates growth by increasing mitosis, cell size, rate of protein synthesis, and the use of fatty acids for energy. Option E. Cortisol – This option is incorrect because cortisol is a glucocorticoid that is released from the adrenal cortex of the adrenal glands, not the posterior pituitary. All hormones released from the adrenal cortex, including cortisol, are steroid hormones. Cortisol stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver to raise blood glucose levels. Gluconeogenesis is the production of glycogen and glucose from noncarbohydrate precursors. Cortisol also stimulates the breakdown of proteins and fats for energy. Since cortisol is a ”stress hormone” that accumulates during long-term stress, it is often used to suppress certain functions that are considered unnecessary in stressful situations. For example, cortisol can suppress the immune system, reproductive system, and body growth.

question.text: A man and a woman have normal skin color but both have one parent with albinism, which is caused by an autosomal recessive allele. If the couple intends on having 2 children, which of the following is the probability that both children will have albinism?

explanation.concept_text: Albinism is an autosomal recessive disease, which we can denote as (aa). Autosomal means that the disease is linked to one of the non-sex chromosomes. A recessive disease is one that requires the presence of two affected alleles to display the affected phenotype. In this case, the recessive allele is denoted as a lowercase ‘a’. In order for an individual to be affected by an autosomal recessive disease, that individual would need to inherit a recessive allele of a given gene from both their mother and father, resulting in an ‘aa’ genotype. We know both the man and the woman have normal skin, which means their genotype can be either homozygous dominant (AA) or heterozygous (Aa). However, since each of them has a parent with albinism (aa), they must have an (Aa) genotype as each of them would have inherited one recessive (a) allele from the parent that has albinism. From here, we can perform a monohybrid cross (Aa x Aa) to determine the probability that one child would have albinism (aa): CC BY 4.0 Therefore, there is a ¼ chance a child of this couple will have albinism (aa). Furthermore, the question states that the couple intends on having 2 children and asks for the probability of both children having albinism. Each child is an independent event, and so, we multiply the probability of the first child having albinism (¼) by the probability of the second child having albinism (¼). Since ¼ x ¼ = 1/16 is the probability that both children will have albinism, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 0 – This option is incorrect because we know both the man and the woman have normal skin, which means their genotype can be either homozygous dominant (AA) or heterozygous (Aa). However, since each of them has a parent with albinism (aa), they must have an (Aa) genotype as each of them would have inherited one recessive (a) allele from the parent that has albinism. From here, we can perform a monohybrid cross (Aa x Aa) to determine the probability that one child would have albinism (aa) which is equal to 1/4.  In order to determine the probability that two children will have albinism; we multiply 1/4 with 1/4 which is equal to 1/16. Option B. 1/2 – This option is incorrect because we know both the man and the woman have normal skin, which means their genotype can be either homozygous dominant (AA) or heterozygous (Aa). However, since each of them has a parent with albinism (aa), they must have an (Aa) genotype as each of them would have inherited one recessive (a) allele from the parent that has albinism. From here, we can perform a monohybrid cross (Aa x Aa) to determine the probability that one child would have albinism (aa) which is equal to 1/4. In order to determine the probability that two children will have albinism; we multiply 1/4 with 1/4 which is equal to 1/16. Option C. 1/4 – This option is incorrect because we know both the man and the woman have normal skin, which means their genotype can be either homozygous dominant (AA) or heterozygous (Aa). However, since each of them has a parent with albinism (aa), they must have an (Aa) genotype as each of them would have inherited one recessive (a) allele from the parent that has albinism. From here, we can perform a monohybrid cross (Aa x Aa) to determine the probability that one child would have albinism (aa) which is equal to 1/4. In order to determine the probability that two children will have albinism; we multiply 1/4 with 1/4 which is equal to 1/16. Option D. 1/8 – This option is incorrect because we know both the man and the woman have normal skin, which means their genotype can be either homozygous dominant (AA) or heterozygous (Aa). However, since each of them has a parent with albinism (aa), they must have an (Aa) genotype as each of them would have inherited one recessive (a) allele from the parent that has albinism. From here, we can perform a monohybrid cross (Aa x Aa) to determine the probability that one child would have albinism (aa) which is equal to 1/4. In order to determine the probability that two children will have albinism; we multiply 1/4 with 1/4 which is equal to 1/16.

question.text: Down syndrome is a condition caused when nondisjunction occurs in meiosis I. Which of the following gametes would be produced from this condition?

options.label: A.
options.text: One gamete will lack chromosome #21 and two would have an extra copy

options.label: B.
options.text: Two gametes will lack chromosome #21 and two would have an extra copy

options.label: C.
options.text: Three gametes will lack chromosome #21 and two would have an extra copy

options.label: D.
options.text: Two gametes will lack chromosome #21 and one would have an extra copy

options.label: E.
options.text: Three gametes will lack chromosome #21 and one would have an extra copy

correct_answer_text: Two gametes will lack chromosome #21 and two would have an extra copy

explanation.concept_text: Nondisjunction is the failure of one or more pairs of homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids to separate normally during nuclear division. It can occur either during meiosis I (anaphase I) or meiosis II (anaphase II). Recall that meiosis is the process by which a diploid parent cell will divide into four haploid daughter cells called gametes. Since anaphase happens twice in meiosis, a nondisjunction event could take place in either meiosis I or meiosis II. The result of a nondisjunction event occurring in either meiosis I or meiosis II will be different. Let’s take a look and see why. As we can see from the image below, if a nondisjunction event takes place during meiosis I, one of the daughter cells is left with one less chromosome while the other daughter cell is left with one extra chromosome (for the sake of explanation, let’s assume nondisjunction only took place on one chromosome, not multiple). Keep in mind, these chromosomes are made up of two sister chromatids that will separate during meiosis II. Once the daughter cells proceed through meiosis II, two of the daughter cells will have one extra copy of a particular chromosome (trisomy) while the other two daughter cells will have one less copy of a particular chromosome (monosomy). Since we know Down syndrome is the result of a nondisjunction event occurring during meiosis I, we can conclude that two gametes will lack a copy of chromosome 21 (0 total copies) while the other two gametes will have an extra copy of chromosome 21 (2 total copies). If one of the gametes containing two copies of chromosome 21 gets fertilized, the resulting zygote will possess three copies of chromosome 21 (the complementary gamete will contribute one of its copies of chromosome 21, 2 + 1 = 3), resulting in Down syndrome (trisomy 21). Since two daughter cells will lack chromosome 21 and two daughter cells will have an extra copy of chromosome 21, Option B is the correct answer. A nondisjunction event that takes place during meiosis II is slightly less detrimental. The result of a nondisjunction event occurring in meiosis II will be two normal daughter cells, one daughter cell with one extra copy of a particular chromosome, and one daughter cell with one less copy of a particular chromosome. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. One gamete will lack chromosome #21 and two would have an extra copy – This option is incorrect because meiosis results in the production of four haploid gametes from one diploid cell. However, in this option choice, only three gametes are produced. A nondisjunction event occurring during meiosis I would result in two gametes lacking a copy of a particular chromosome and two gametes having an extra copy of a particular chromosome. Option C. Three gametes will lack chromosome #21 and two would have an extra copy – This option is incorrect because meiosis results in the production of four haploid gametes from one diploid cell. However, in this option choice, a total of five gametes are produced. A nondisjunction event occurring during meiosis I would result in two gametes lacking a copy of a particular chromosome and two gametes having an extra copy of a particular chromosome. Option D. Two gametes will lack chromosome #21 and one would have an extra copy – This option is incorrect because meiosis results in the production of four haploid gametes from one diploid cell. However, in this option choice, only three gametes are produced. A nondisjunction event occurring during meiosis I would result in two gametes lacking a copy of a particular chromosome and two gametes having an extra copy of a particular chromosome. Option E. Three gametes will lack chromosome #21 and one would have an extra copy – This option is incorrect because Down syndrome is the result of a nondisjunction event occurring on chromosome 21 during meiosis I. This will result in two gametes lacking a copy of chromosome 21 and two gametes having an extra copy of chromosome 21. Since this answer choice states that three gametes will lack chromosome 21 and one will have an extra copy, this option is incorrect.

question.text: What is the effect of the hormone released by the parathyroid gland?

explanation.concept_text: The parathyroid gland , four pea-shaped structures attached to the back of the thyroid, releases the parathyroid hormone . The parathyroid hormone raises calcium concentrations in the blood by triggering calcium release from the bones and stimulating osteoclast proliferation. Osteoclasts are bone cells that resorb the bone matrix and release minerals back to the blood. In addition to increasing blood calcium levels, the parathyroid hormone increases renal calcium reabsorption and renal phosphate excretion. The parathyroid hormone also increases calcium phosphate uptake from the gut by increasing the renal production of vitamin D-derived steroids. The secretion of the parathyroid hormone is regulated by calcium levels in the blood, and parathyroid glands grow or shrink accordingly. Understand for the test that the overall effect of this hormone is to raise blood calcium levels. Since the question is asking for the effect of the hormone released by the parathyroid gland and the parathyroid hormone is the only hormone produced by the parathyroid gland, Option A. Increases blood calcium levels is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Decreases blood calcium levels – This option is incorrect because the parathyroid hormone increases blood calcium levels. The parathyroid hormone raises calcium concentrations in the blood by triggering calcium release from the bones and stimulating osteoclast proliferation. Calcitonin, instead, is a hormone that decreases blood calcium levels. Calcitonin is produced by the thyroid gland. It stimulates osteoblast activity which builds bone by using up the calcium in the blood. Calcitonin also decreases osteoclast activity and number. Option C. Inhibits gastric motility – This option is incorrect because the parathyroid hormone does not affect gastric motility. The parathyroid hormone instead acts on the bone matrix by stimulating osteoclasts: bone cells that break down bone and release minerals back to the blood. Gastric motility is instead affected by gastrointestinal hormones such as cholecystokinin. Cholecystokinin is a hormone secreted by the small intestine in response to the presence of fat. Cholecystokinin not only stimulates the gallbladder to release its digestive enzymes, but also decreases the motility of the stomach. This inhibition of gastric motility allows more time for the duodenum to digest fat. Option D. Increases the metabolic rate – This option is incorrect because the parathyroid hormone does not affect metabolic rate. The parathyroid hormone instead acts on the bone matrix by stimulating osteoclasts: bone cells that break down bone and release minerals back to the blood. T4 (thyroxine) and T3 (triiodothyronine) are hormones that increase metabolic rate. These hormones are released from the thyroid gland. Both T4 and T3 are derived from the amino acid tyrosine and require iodine in the process of assembly. Since these hormones are lipid-soluble, they can freely pass through the membrane. An increase in T4 and T3 will result in an increased body metabolism (more calories being burnt) and an increased heart rate. Option E. Stimulates release of cortisol – This option is incorrect because the parathyroid hormone is not a tropic hormone, meaning that it does not target other endocrine glands. Further, the parathyroid hormone does not stimulate the release of cortisol from the adrenal cortex. The parathyroid hormone instead acts on the bone matrix by stimulating osteoclasts: bone cells that break down bone and release minerals back to the blood. Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), instead, stimulates the release of cortisol. Once ACTH is released from the anterior pituitary, it stimulates the adrenal cortex to release cortisol. Cortisol, as well as other glucocorticoids, stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver to raise blood glucose levels. Cortisol also stimulates the breakdown of proteins and fats for energy.

question.text: Based on the image below, what would be expected in the resulting gametes?

options.label: A.
options.text: One gamete will have an extra copy of the purple chromosome and one gamete will have no copy of the purple chromosome

options.label: B.
options.text: One gamete will have an extra copy of the green chromosome and one gamete will have no copy of the green chromosome

options.label: C.
options.text: Both gametes will have extra copies of the purple chromosomes

options.label: D.
options.text: Neither gamete will have a copy of the green chromosome

options.label: E.
options.text: Both gametes will have the normal amount of chromosomes

correct_answer_text: One gamete will have an extra copy of the purple chromosome and one gamete will have no copy of the purple chromosome

explanation.concept_text: Nondisjunction is a genetic error that results when one or more chromosomes, or sister chromatids, fail to separate during anaphase of meiosis or mitosis. Since the question mentions that the cell in the image will result in gametes, we can know that the image in the question depicts a nondisjunction event occurring during meiosis II . Notice that this image only depicts one of the haploid daughter cells. We can safely assume that there is another daughter cell not imaged that is proceeding through meiosis II as usual. If nondisjunction occurs during meiosis II, such as in the question above, one of the gametes will possess two copies of a particular chromosome, the purple chromosome, and the other gamete will lack the chromosome (again, the purple chromosome). We can assume that the other haploid daughter cell proceeded through anaphase II normally, resulting in two gametes with the expected number of chromosomes. In total, from one mother cell, there will be the production of four gametes, two of which are normal and two of which are abnormal as a result of the nondisjunction event depicted in the image above. The figure below shows nondisjunction occurring in meiosis I and II. Note the similarities between the image in the question and nondisjunction in meiosis II in the figure below. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. One gamete will have an extra copy of the green chromosome and one gamete will have no copy of the green chromosome – This option is incorrect because the green chromosome successfully separated, while the purple chromosome did not, indicating nondisjunction of the purple chromosome. Therefore, the gametes will each have one copy of the green chromosome. Option C. Both gametes will have extra copies of the purple chromosome – This option is incorrect because if nondisjunction prevents the chromatids of the purple chromosome from successfully separating, we can conclude that one of the gametes resulting from this cell will keep both copies of the purple chromosome, while the other gamete will not possess any copies of the purple chromosome. Option D. Neither gamete will have a copy of the green chromosome – This option is incorrect because based on the image, the nondisjunction event is occurring on the purple chromosome, not the green chromosome. The sister chromatids of the green chromosome successfully separated, meaning that both gametes resulting from this cell will have one copy of the green chromosome. Option E. Both gametes will have the normal amount of chromosomes – This option is incorrect because whenever a nondisjunction event occurs during meiosis or mitosis, the daughter cells will have an abnormal number of chromosome copies. In this case, because a nondisjunction event is occurring on the purple chromosome, one of the resulting gametes will have an extra copy of the purple chromosome and the other gamete will have no copies of the purple chromosome. Therefore, while the gametes will have normal amounts of the green chromosome, they will not have normal amounts of the purple chromosome.

question.text: What molecule is completely removed from the filtrate and sent back to the blood?

explanation.concept_text: The process of urine formation occurs in the nephron. The nephron is the functional unit of the kidney that functions to reabsorb nutrients, salts, and water. Filtration occurs in the renal corpuscle of the nephron. The fluid that goes through the glomerulus to the rest of the nephron is called the filtrate . The filtrate is then pushed into the Bowman's capsule to enter the nephron itself. Particles that are too large to filter through the glomerulus, such as blood cells or immunoglobulins, remain in the circulatory system. This process of filtration is driven by the hydrostatic pressure of blood. The filtrate then moves through the proximal convoluted tubule for reabsorption . Reabsorption is the process in which a substance is pulled out of the nephron and brought back into the blood. Most reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule. In the proximal convoluted tubule, glucose, salts, and amino acids can be reabsorbed from the filtrate and returned to the blood. More reabsorption occurs in the distal convoluted tubule. In the distal convoluted tubule, more glucose, ions, and water can be reabsorbed from the filtrate. It is important to note that glucose is the only substance that is completely reabsorbed during this process. In other words, despite the fact that glucose makes it through the filtration process, absolutely no glucose remains in the nephron for excretion. Hence, healthy individuals should not have any glucose present in their urine, since the entirety of glucose gets reabsorbed prior to excretion. Secretion is the process in which a substance is removed from the blood and sent back into the nephron. Like reabsorption, most secretion occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule. During secretion, substances such as acids, bases, ammonia, drugs, and ions can be secreted by both passive and active transport. Since glucose is the only molecule that is completely reabsorbed (removed from the filtrate and brought back into the blood), Option A. Glucose is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Calcium – This option is incorrect because while calcium is filtered at the glomerulus and reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule, it does not undergo complete reabsorption. In other words, the proximal convoluted tubule only brings a portion of the filtered calcium back into the blood and the rest remains in the filtrate until it is excreted through urine. Option C. Sodium – This option is incorrect because while sodium is actively reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule, loop of Henle, and distal convoluted tubule, not all sodium is reabsorbed, and it can also be transported from the blood into the nephron. Sodium can be consistently moved both out and into the nephron, and a portion of sodium is always present in the filtrate and excreted through urine. Option D. Urea – This option is incorrect because while urea is reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule and collecting duct, it is also transported into the nephron in the proximal convoluted tubule. Urea can also re-enter the tubule at the loop of Henle as a part of a process known as urea recycling. Therefore, urea remains in the filtrate until it is excreted through urine. Option E. Large proteins – This option is incorrect because most proteins are too large to pass through the glomerulus and reach the rest of the nephron. Since large proteins cannot make it through the filtration process, they are not present in the filtrate to begin with and therefore cannot be reabsorbed into the blood. Some examples of these large proteins include immunoglobulins.

question.text: Which is TRUE of the Hardy-Weinberg principle?

options.label: A.
options.text: Equilibrium is best maintained in a small population

options.label: B.
options.text: Can only occur when gene flow is present

options.label: C.
options.text: Genetic equilibrium requires a lack of evolution

options.label: E.
options.text: Increased rate of mutations accelerates the equilibrium

correct_answer_text: Genetic equilibrium requires a lack of evolution

explanation.concept_text: The Hardy-Weinberg principle states that populations are in genetic equilibrium if their allele frequencies do not change from generation to generation. The Hardy-Weinberg principle is used to determine allele frequencies within a population that is in genetic equilibrium. Allele frequencies can be determined via the following equations: p + q =1 p 2 + 2pq + q 2 = 1 p = frequency of the dominant allele q = frequency of the recessive allele p 2 = frequency of homozygous dominant individuals 2pq = frequency of heterozygous individuals q 2 = frequency of homozygous recessive individuals In order for a population to be in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, the following conditions must be met: Since there needs to be a lack of evolutionary change to a population for there to be Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Equilibrium is best maintained in a small population – This option is incorrect because one of the conditions required to meet Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is a large population to decrease the effect of genetic drift. Recall that genetic drift is the random increase or decrease in allele frequency by chance. Genetic drift has a larger effect on small populations. Option B. Can only occur when gene flow is present – This option is incorrect because one of the conditions required to meet Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is no gene flow. Gene flow is the introduction or removal of alleles from a population due to the migration of individuals within that population. Gene flow affects the allele frequency of the population and therefore should be eliminated to achieve Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Option D. Natural selection is required – This option is incorrect because one of the conditions required to meet Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is no natural selection. Recall that natural selection is the increase and decrease of allele frequencies in order to adapt/evolve to the environment. The best alleles are selected for while the worst alleles are selected against. Since natural selection is the foundation of evolution and evolution requires a change in allele frequencies, natural selection must be eliminated to achieve Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Option E. Increased rate of mutations accelerates the equilibrium – This option is incorrect because one of the conditions required to meet Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is no mutations. Mutations are changes to a DNA sequence, resulting in new and heritable alleles. Mutations introduce new alleles into a population and would therefore disrupt, not accelerate, Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

question.text: The immune system is used to help the body fight off infections from foreign invaders. What cells are the most abundant and the first to attack foreign infectious agents?

explanation.concept_text: The first line of defense of the human immune system is innate immunity . Innate immunity is also known as nonspecific immunity because it provides generalized protection against foreign invaders. Neutrophils are phagocytic cells that are part of the innate immune response . These cells are the most abundant type of white blood cell and are generally the first to enter the infected tissues/organs to elicit an immune response. They are followed by lymphocytes (specifically, natural killer cells), and then monocytes/macrophages. Neutrophils destruct pathogens via phagocytosis. Phagocytosis is the process in which a cell (in this case, a neutrophil) engulfs foreign particles (in this case, a pathogen). While neutrophils “eat” pathogens, they don’t present antigens for recognition by T cells because they are not involved in the adaptive immune response. Since neutrophils are the first responders to foreign invaders as well as the most abundant type of white blood cell, Option B is the correct answer. Aside from the innate immune response performed by cells like neutrophils, the body also develops an adaptive immune response when attacked by pathogens. Adaptive immunity is a specific line of defense that targets specific antigens. The responses of the adaptive immune system can be categorized into the cell-mediated response and the antibody-mediated (humoral) response. The cell-mediated response uses T cells (cytotoxic T cells and helper T cells) and is effective against infected non-self cells. The antibody-mediated response uses B cells (plasma B cells and memory B cells) and the antibodies they produce to respond to antigens or pathogens that circulate in the lymph or blood. Here is a visualization of the immune cells of the immune system: CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Macrophages – This option is incorrect because while macrophages are phagocytic cells that are involved in innate immunity, they are not the most abundant immune cells. Neutrophils, instead, are the most abundant immune cells that are the first to respond to a pathogen. Macrophages develop from monocytes. Monocytes are the immature form of macrophages that circulate in blood until they move into tissues via diapedesis (passage of blood cells through the walls of capillaries). Option C. Helper T cells – This option is incorrect because T cells are a part of adaptive immunity. T cells originate in the bone marrow, but mature in the thymus. While these cells have antigen receptors, they do not produce antibodies themselves. Instead, these cells check molecules displayed by non-self cells and directly act on cells to protect the body from infection. Helper T cells (also known as CD4 T cells), specifically, are a derivative of T cells. When an antigen is presented on major histocompatibility complex II (MHC II), naïve T cells will become activated and proliferate into helper T cells. Helper T cells play a role in both the innate and adaptive immune response. In innate immunity, helper T cells bind macrophages that can engulf pathogens. In adaptive immunity, helper T cells produce interleukins to activate T cells, B cells, and macrophages. While helper T cells play a role in the innate immune system, they are not the first to attack foreign invaders. Neutrophils, instead, are the first cells to attack foreign invaders. Option D. Plasma cells – This option is incorrect because plasma cells are a derivative of B cells that release antibodies to fight infection. B cells originate and mature in the bone marrow, and are activated in response to antigens. Plasma cells, specifically, are B cells that circulate in blood and release specific, free antibodies that destroy antigens. Plasma cells are part of the adaptive immune response, making their response much slower than that of the innate immune system. Neutrophils, instead, are the first cells to attack foreign invaders. Option E. Memory cells – This option is incorrect because memory cells are derivatives of B cells that are used for “remembering” the antigen of a particular pathogen. B cells originate and mature in the bone marrow, and are activated in response to antigens. Memory cells, specifically, circulate the body and function to eliminate subsequent invasion by the same antigen. If a pathogen were to return, memory cells would recognize the antigen and mount a stronger and quicker immune response. Memory cells are part of the adaptive immune system, making their response much slower than that of the innate immune system. Neutrophils, instead, are the first cells to attack foreign invaders, and are by far the most abundant.

question.text: Which of the following organisms is most abundant in a prairie biome?

explanation.concept_text: Biomes are regions with common environmental characteristics. In order to answer this question, we must first understand that a prairie biome is simply another name for a temperate grassland . An example of a temperate grassland is the North American prairie. Temperate grasslands can be characterized by their fertile soil, uneven seasonal rainfall, and seasonal droughts and fires. Since the most abundant organism that can be found in the prairie biome is grass, Option A is the correct answer. Another strategy to arrive at the correct answer for this question is understanding that grass is a primary producer . Primary producers are autotrophs that convert the sun's energy into chemical energy. Recall that primary producers are located at the lowest trophic level of the ecological pyramid and therefore belong to the trophic level that contains the most biomass within the whole ecological pyramid. (Biomass is the total mass of all living organisms.) So long as we are confident that grass is an organism that exists in the prairie biome, we can safely assume that grass is the most abundant organism of the answer choices listed, since it is the only answer choice that is a primary producer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Foxes – This option is incorrect because while foxes do exist in the prairie biome, they are not the most abundant organism. Grass, instead, is the most abundant organism of the prairie biome which supplies energy to many of the other organisms that are found in the prairie biome. Option C. Birds – This option is incorrect because while birds do exist in the prairie biome, they are not the most abundant organism. Grass, instead, is the most abundant organism of the prairie biome which supplies energy to many of the other organisms that are found in the prairie biome. Option D. Gazelles – This option is incorrect because while gazelles do exist in the prairie biome, they are not the most abundant organism. Grass, instead, is the most abundant organism of the prairie biome which supplies energy to many of the other organisms that are found in the prairie biome. Option E. Vines – This option is incorrect because while vines are primary producers that occupy the lowest trophic level of the ecological pyramid with the most amount of biomass, vines are not found in prairie biomes. Vines, instead, are abundant in tropical rainforests. Tropical rainforests are a type of land biome that has a high but stable temperature and humidity, as well as heavy rainfall. Tropical rainforests are the most diverse biome. Epiphytes, plants that grow commensally on other plants, can be found in this biome. Since vines are epiphytes, they can be found in the tropical rainforest biome.

question.text: Which of the following cells is the most differentiated?

explanation.concept_text: Cell differentiation is a process by which cells become specialized in structure and function. Hence, early embryonic cells tend to be less differentiated, while cells that have continued through differentiation via embryonic development tend to be more differentiated. Once a sperm and ovum nuclei fuse, a diploid zygote forms. The zygote is the least differentiated embryonic cell. This zygote undergoes rapid cell division, also known as cleavage, to form a morula. A morula is a solid ball of ~8 cells. As cleavage continues, liquid fills the morula and pushes its cells outward to form a circular cavity surrounded by a single layer of cells. The single layer of cells is called a blastula and the circular cavity is called a blastocoel. A blastula has ~128 cells. As these cells undergo more cell division, the gastrula is formed. The gastrula contains three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. These germ layers later give rise to their subsequent tissues. Cells continue to divide after gastrulation and differentiate into specific tissues and organs through a process called organogenesis. These specialized tissues are the most differentiated form of cells. Lymphocytes are primary agents of the immune response. These cells are leukocytes that originate in the bone marrow and concentrate in lymphatic tissues such as lymph nodes, thymus gland, and spleen. Unlike the other answer choices mentioned which are at early embryonic or undifferentiated states, lymphocytes are a highly differentiated cell. Since lymphocytes are specialized cells of the immune system that are most differentiated out of all the options, Option C. Lymphocyte is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Zygote – This option is incorrect because a zygote is a single diploid cell, resulting from the fusion of a sperm and an egg, that does not have a specialized function. Since a zygote requires more cell division to differentiate into cells with specialized structures and functions, it is not the most differentiated cell out of all the options. In fact, the zygote is one of the least differentiated types of cells, as it has yet to undergo any meaningful cellular differentiation. Option B. Neoblast – This option is incorrect because neoblasts are undifferentiated, pluripotent stem cells found in planarians. Planarians, also known as flatworms, belong to the domain Eukarya and kingdom Animalia. Due to their neoblasts, planarians have a remarkable capacity to regenerate. For example, when a planarian is cut in half, both halves will regenerate a fully functional organism. Since neoblasts are undifferentiated stem cells that have yet to develop into cells with specialized structures and functions, they are not the most differentiated cells out of all the options. Option D. Blastocyst – This option is incorrect because blastocysts are blastulas that are implanted into the endometrium. Cells of the blastocyst are pluripotent. Pluripotent stem cells can give rise to all tissue types, but not an entire organism. Since blastocysts consist of stem cells that have yet to develop into cells with specialized structures and functions, they are not the most differentiated cells out of all the options. Option E. Embryonic stem cell — This option is incorrect because embryonic stem cells are pluripotent cells that come from the inner cell mass of a blastocyst. Pluripotent stem cells can give rise to all tissue types, but not an entire organism. Since embryonic stem cells have the potential to develop into any type of cell in the body, they are not the most differentiated cells out of all the options.

question.text: What is the best measure of fitness?

options.label: A.
options.text: Length of time an organism’s offspring survives

options.label: B.
options.text: Amount of care an organism provides its offspring

options.label: C.
options.text: Number of offspring that reach adulthood

options.label: D.
options.text: Length of time an organism can survive

options.label: E.
options.text: Number of fertile offspring that reach reproductive age

correct_answer_text: Number of fertile offspring that reach reproductive age

explanation.concept_text: Fitness is the quantitative representation of natural and sexual selection in evolutionary biology. It is important to note that the term “fitness” has a very different meaning in the context of evolution than in day-to-day life. In the context of evolution, the fitness of an organism is measured by the number of fertile offspring an organism can produce that can reach reproductive age. Always remember when asked about fitness, both conditions must be analyzed: the ability to produce fertile (viable) offspring and the ability of those offspring to survive and reach reproductive age. For example, if an organism produces a lot of offspring, but those offspring die during the early stages of life, the organism cannot be considered “fit”. Since the number of fertile offspring that reach reproductive age is the best description of the measure of fitness, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Length of time an organism’s offspring survives – This option is incorrect because while the length of time an organism’s offspring survives is one of the conditions that determine fitness of an organism, it is not the only condition that defines fitness. The number of fertile offspring and the ability of those offspring to survive and reach reproductive age are the best measures of fitness, and must be evaluated together to determine the overall fitness of an organism. This answer choice makes no mention as to whether the offspring are fertile (or how many offspring there are); hence, it is an insufficient measure of fitness. Option B. Amount of care an organism provides its offspring – This option is incorrect because when analyzing an organism’s fitness, it is important to take note of two conditions only: the number of fertile offspring that an organism produces and the ability of those offspring to survive and reach reproductive age. The amount of care an organism provides to its offspring is species-dependent and doesn’t always necessarily increase fitness. While the amount of parental care cannot be used as a measure of fitness, it can help us determine the parental strategy of a species (K-selected vs. R-selected). K-selected populations demonstrate strong parental care (but tend to produce fewer offspring), whereas R-selected populations demonstrate little to no parental care (but produce a higher quantity of those offspring). Option C. Number of offspring that reach adulthood – This option is incorrect because when measuring fitness, two conditions need to be analyzed: the ability of offspring to survive and reach sexual maturity and the number of offspring that are fertile. This option only describes the ability of the offspring to survive, but not the fertility of the offspring; hence, it is an insufficient measure of fitness. Option D. Length of time an organism can survive – This option is incorrect because while increasing the length of time an organism survives may increase fitness, if the organism doesn’t reach sexual maturity, there will be no effect because the organism will not be able to produce any offspring. An organism must be able to survive long enough to reach reproductive age (which was not directly stated in this answer choice) as well as produce a large number of fertile offspring in order to be considered fit. Fitness is a measurement based on those two conditions and since both of these conditions were not analyzed, this option is incorrect.

question.text: In organisms such as birds and reptiles, the yolk sac contains nourishing yolk. However, in humans, the yolk sac serves a different purpose. Which of the following is its purpose in humans?

options.label: B.
options.text: First site of red blood cell synthesis

options.label: D.
options.text: Site for white blood cell synthesis

correct_answer_text: First site of red blood cell synthesis

explanation.concept_text: The yolk sac is a membranous sac attached to an embryo formed by cells of the hypoblast next to the embryonic disk. The yolk sac is not a structure of the embryo itself, but rather, it is an extraembryonic structure used to support the embryo during development. Whether or not the embryo is a placental animal (mammals) or an egg-laying animal (birds and reptiles) will determine the function of the yolk sac. In egg-laying animals such as birds and reptiles, the embryos aren’t afforded a placenta for nourishment. For this reason, the yolk sac will provide the embryo with nutrients until the animal hatches out of the egg. The yolk sac first digests enclosed yolk (the nutrient-bearing portion of an egg), then transfers its nutrients to the embryo through blood vessels. In contrast to egg-laying animals, in placental animals, the yolk sac provides little nourishment to the embryo. This is because the placenta, instead, is the structure that provides nutrients to the embryo. The yolk sac in placental animals helps develop red blood cells. Since humans are placental animals and the yolk sac of placental animals functions as the first site of red blood cell synthesis, Option B is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Uric acid storage – This option is incorrect because uric acid storage is a function that is not performed by the yolk sac. It is instead performed by the allantois in egg-laying animals only. The allantois is a sac that buds off from the archenteron and eventually encircles the embryo, forming below the chorion. In egg-laying animals, the allantois initially stores waste products as uric acid, and later fuses with the chorion to form a membrane used for gas exchange. Option C. Site to excrete wastes – This option is incorrect because providing a site for waste excretion is a function that is not performed by the yolk sac. It is instead performed by the allantois in placental animals only. In placental animals, the allantois will transport waste from the fetus to the placenta for the mother to excrete. The allantois will also eventually become the umbilical cord, a structure that connects the embryo and the placenta. The umbilical cord helps transport gases, nutrients, and wastes. In adults, the allantois becomes the urinary bladder. Option D. Site for white blood cell synthesis – This option is incorrect because providing a site for white blood cell synthesis is a function that is not performed by the yolk sac. White blood cells are synthesized in the lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus gland. In placental animals, the yolk sac is the first site for red blood cell synthesis. Do not confuse this with white blood cell synthesis. Option E. Oxygen transport – This option is incorrect because the yolk sac does not function to transport oxygen. Oxygen gets transported across the placenta to the fetus through the umbilical cord. The umbilical cord, a structure that connects the embryo and the placenta, helps transport gases, nutrients, and wastes. The yolk sac is not responsible for any type of gas exchange.

question.text: Which part of the sarcomere contains myosin only?

explanation.concept_text: Sarcomeres are the functional units of striated muscle fibers (skeletal and cardiac muscles). These repeating units are what give striated muscles their striated appearance (long, thin strips). Sarcomeres are made up of filament proteins that slide past one another during contraction. For the purposes of the test, the two most important filament proteins are thin filaments (made up of actin polymers) and thick filaments (made up of myosin ). When the muscle contracts, these filaments slide past one another, a process known as the sliding filament theory. It is important to note that during contraction, the sarcomeres will shorten but the filaments remain the same length. It is simply the filaments sliding past one another that results in the shortening of a sarcomere. The image below illustrates a sarcomere. The Z-lines are the boundaries of a single sarcomere that anchors thin actin filaments. The M-line is the center of the sarcomere. The I-bands are the regions containing thin actin filaments only. The H-zone is the region containing thick myosin filaments only. The A-band is the length of a single thick myosin filament. It is important to note that the H-zone and I-band reduce during muscle contraction, while the A-band does not. Since the H-zone is the part of the sarcomere that contains myosin only, Option D . H-zone is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Z-line – This option is incorrect because the Z-line represents the border of an individual sarcomere that does not contain any myosin. The Z-line instead anchors the thin actin filaments. As the myofilaments slide over one another during muscle contraction, the Z-lines approach each other, leading to the shortening of the sarcomere. Option B. Thin filaments – This option is incorrect because thin filaments of sarcomeres are made up of actin polymers and do not contain any myosin. These actin polymers are anchored to the Z line(s), which is/are the border of the sarcomere. Thick filaments, instead, are made up of myosin polymers. Option C. I-band – This option is incorrect because the I-band is a region containing thin actin filaments only and therefore does not contain any myosin. It is important to note that the I-bands reduce during muscle contraction, because overlap between the myosin and actin filaments increases. Option E. A-band – This option is incorrect because the A-band contains both myosin and actin. The A-band is the length of a single thick myosin filament within a sarcomere – however, this length also overlaps with actin. It is important to note that when a muscle contracts, the A-band does not change in length, as the myosin filament itself does not shorten. Only the H-zone and I-band will decrease in length due to the increased overlap between myosin and actin filaments.

question.text: What structure does the telencephalon develop into?

explanation.concept_text: The vertebrate brain consists of the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain. Each of these regions develops from a specific subdivision of the embryonic brain.
