The forebrain is the largest and most important brain region. The forebrain develops from the telencephalon and the diencephalon . The telencephalon gives rise to the cerebrum. The cerebrum functions to coordinate movement and regulate body temperature. The diencephalon gives rise to the hypothalamus, thalamus, and pineal gland. The hypothalamus is responsible for functions including water balance, blood pressure regulation, body temperature regulation, and many more. The thalamus relays sensory information between the spinal cord and the cerebral cortex. The pineal gland secretes melatonin to maintain circadian rhythms: a natural cycle of the body that repeats roughly every 24 hours. The midbrain functions as a relay center for visual and auditory impulses, as well as motor control. The midbrain develops from the mesencephalon . The hindbrain is the posterior region of the brain. The hindbrain develops from the metencephalon and the myelencephalon . The metencephalon gives rise to the pons and cerebellum. The pons is a relay center that allows communication between the cerebral cortex and the cerebellum. The cerebellum maintains balance, hand-eye coordination, timing of rapid movements, and motor skills. The myelencephalon gives rise to the medulla oblongata. The medulla oblongata regulates breathing, heart rate, and gastrointestinal activity. Since the telencephalon develops into the cerebrum, Option C. Cerebrum is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Cerebellum – This option is incorrect because the metencephalon develops into the cerebellum. The cerebellum is a part of the hindbrain that maintains balance, hand-eye coordination, timing of rapid movements, and motor skills. Option B. Thalamus – This option is incorrect because the diencephalon develops into the thalamus. The thalamus is a part of the forebrain that relays sensory information between the spinal cord and the cerebral cortex. Option D. Pons – This option is incorrect because the metencephalon develops into the pons. The pons is a part of the hindbrain that functions as a relay center for communication between the cerebral cortex and the cerebellum. Option E. Brainstem – This option is incorrect because the brainstem develops from multiple different parts of the embryonic brain. The brainstem includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata. The mesencephalon gives rise to the midbrain. The midbrain functions as a relay center for visual and auditory impulses, as well as motor control. The metencephalon gives rise to the pons. The pons is a part of the hindbrain that functions as a relay center for communication between the cerebral cortex and the cerebellum. The myelencephalon gives rise to the medulla oblongata. The medulla oblongata is a part of the hindbrain that regulates breathing, heart rate, and gastrointestinal activity.

question.text: A defect in which structure of a plant would prevent an ovule from being produced?

explanation.concept_text: Angiosperms are flower-bearing plants that are the dominant land plant form. Examples of angiosperms include fruits, maple, oaks, grass, etc. The flower is the reproductive structure of an angiosperm and the major structures of the flower include the pistil , stamen , and the petals . The pistil is the female reproductive structure, and it is composed of three parts: the ovary , the style , and the stigma . The stigma is a sticky landing site for pollen. The style is the tube that leads from the stigma down to the ovary. The ovary lies at the base of the style and is the site where ovules are produced. Hence, the ovary is also referred to as the “egg-bearing” structure of an angiosperm. Recall that ovules contain the female gamete of the plant which are fertilized by pollen to develop into a seed! Since the ovary produces ovules and the ovary is a component of the pistil, a defect in the pistil would prevent an ovule from being produced; therefore, Option B. Pistil is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Stigma – This option is incorrect because while the stigma is a part of the pistil, it is not responsible for the production of ovules. The stigma, instead, is a sticky landing site for pollen. Once pollen lands on the stigma, it travels through the style to reach the ovary. The pollen then fertilizes the ovules, causing the development of a seed. Option C. Stamen – This option is incorrect because the stamen is the male reproductive structure of angiosperms. Stamens are composed of the anther and filament. The anther is the chamber where pollen develops. Hence, the anther is also referred to as the ”pollen-bearing” structure of an angiosperm. The filament is a long stalk that supports the anther. Since the stamen is a male reproductive structure, it cannot be responsible for producing an ovule. Option D. Sepal – This option is incorrect because the sepal is part of the calyx of a flower that encases and protects the flower bud. The sepal may also function to attract pollinators. Since the sepal is not a part of the female reproductive structure, it cannot be responsible for producing an ovule. Option E. Petal – This option is incorrect because petals are a component of the flower that is not a part of any reproductive structure. Hence, petals cannot be responsible for producing an ovule. The primary function of petals is to attract pollinators.

question.text: Where are embryonic stem cells derived from?

explanation.concept_text: Once a sperm fertilizes an egg to form a zygote , the zygote undergoes cleavage. Cleavage is the rapid cell division of the zygote without cell growth. The zygote then becomes a morula . The morula is a solid ball of ~8 cells. As cell division continues, liquid fills the morula and pushes its cells outward to form a circular cavity surrounded by a single layer of cells. The fluid-filled cavity is called a blastocoel, and the layer of cells is called a blastula . The blastula has ~128 cells. In humans, the blastula is called the blastocyst when it implants into the endometrium. Stem cells are undifferentiated or partially differentiated cells that can develop into a variety of cell types. There are four types of stem cells. Totipotent stem cells can give rise to any and all human cells, and even form an entire functional organism. The cells of the morula are totipotent. Pluripotent stem cells can give rise to all tissue types, but not an entire organism. The cells of the blastocyst are pluripotent. Multipotent stem cells can give rise to a limited range of cells within a tissue type. Unipotent stem cells can only give rise to a single cell type. Embryonic stem cells specifically refer to those derived from the inner cell mass of the blastocyst. These cells are pluripotent; hence, they are capable of regenerating. It is important to note that pluripotent cells are advantageous over totipotent stem cells from a research perspective. While totipotent stem cells can give rise to any and all human cells, they can also give rise to extra embryonic tissues that are less useful. Since embryonic stem cells are pluripotent cells isolated from the blastocyst, Option A. Blastocyst is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Bone marrow – This option is incorrect because the bone marrow does not contain pluripotent embryonic stem cells. There are two types of bone marrow: yellow and red. The yellow bone marrow contains adipose cells for fat storage. The red bone marrow contains blood stem cells for hemopoiesis, also known as red blood cell development. While the red bone marrow does contain stem cells, these stem cells are multipotent because they can only develop into blood cells. Hence, blood stem cells of the red bone marrow are not embryonic stem cells. Option C. Zygote – This option is incorrect because embryonic stem cells are not isolated from the zygote. In fact, embryonic stem cells are extracted from the inner cell mass of the blastocyst. The zygote is a diploid cell that results from the fusion of a sperm and an egg. Hence, the zygote consists of a single cell that is difficult to isolate due to its location. In order to isolate embryonic stem cells, the zygote must undergo cleavage to become a morula, then a blastocyst. Furthermore, since a zygote is totipotent, it is not an embryonic stem cell by definition (embryonic stem cells refer to the inner cell mass of the blastocyst, a later embryonic stage than the zygote). Option D. Ovaries – This option is incorrect because ovaries are a structure of the female reproductive system that produce eggs. Since eggs are haploid cells that must be fused with sperm to form a diploid zygote, it does not contain any embryonic stem cells that can be isolated. Option E . Placenta – Thi s option is incorrect because the placenta is a blend of maternal and embryonic tissue that functions to exchange gases, nutrients, and wastes. The placenta produces hormones for maintaining pregnancy. If implantation occurs, the placenta secretes chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in order to maintain the corpus luteum. By the end of the first trimester, the placenta reaches full development and secretes its own estrogen and progesterone, lowering hCG levels. The placenta also serves as a barrier to protect the fetus against harmful substances, but simultaneously allows beneficial substances to pass through. For example, maternal antibodies such as IgG are able to cross the placenta and enter the fetus.

question.text: An inability to produce lymphocytes would cause what type of disease?

explanation.concept_text: Lymphocytes are leukocytes (white blood cells) that function as primary agents of the immune response. These cells originate in the bone marrow and concentrate in lymphatic tissue such as the lymph nodes, thymus gland, and spleen. There are three main types of lymphocytes: B cells, T cells, and natural killer (NK) cells. B cells are antibody-producing lymphocytes that are activated in response to antigens. These cells originate and mature in the bone marrow. The plasma membrane of B cells contain antigen-receptor antibodies. When antigens bind to these receptors, B cells proliferate and produce daughter B cells. There are two main types of B cells: plasma cells and memory cells. Plasma cells are B cells that circulate in the blood and release specific, free antibodies in response to antigens. Memory cells are long-lived B cells that do not release antibodies in response to immediate antigen invasion. These cells, instead, circulate the body and proliferate until there is a subsequent invasion by the same antigen. T cells are lymphocytes that check molecules displayed by self cells presenting non-self antigens. These cells originate in the bone marrow, but mature in the thymus. When T cells are exposed to non-self cells, it can divide to produce four kinds of cells: cytotoxic T cells, helper T cells, suppressor T cells, and memory T cells. Cytotoxic T cells are killer cells that recognize and destroy by releasing perforin: a protein that can puncture cells. Helper T cells stimulate the activation of B cells, cytotoxic T cells, and suppressor T cells. Suppressor T cells carry out negative feedback in the immune system and memory T cells are similar in function to memory B cells. NK cells are lymphocytes that attack virus-infected cells or tumors. Unlike B cells and T cells, these cells are a part of innate immunity; hence, they are not involved in specific attacks against antigens. If a patient is unable to produce lymphocytes (or lack other types of immune cells), their immune system will fail to recognize and fight off infections. Since immunodeficiency describes a state in which an immune system is unable to defend the body from infectious diseases, Option C. Immunodeficiency is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Autoimmune disease – This option is incorrect because an autoimmune disease is not caused by an absence or lack of lymphocytes. Autoimmune diseases, instead, occur when the immune system is unable to distinguish between healthy self-cells and infected non-self cells. Hence, the immune system attacks the body’s own uninfected, healthy tissue. Some examples of autoimmune diseases include lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, and type 1 diabetes. Option B. Hypothermia – This option is incorrect because hypothermia is not caused by an absence or lack of lymphocytes. Hypothermia is a condition that occurs when core body temperature drops below 95°F (35°C) due to exposure to cold conditions. While hypothermia does impair the immune system and inhibits inflammation, the condition itself is not caused by a problem in the immune system. Option D. Down syndrome – This option is incorrect because Down syndrome is not caused by an absence or lack of lymphocytes. Down syndrome is instead caused by nondisjunction. Nondisjunction is the failure of one or more chromosome pairs or chromatids to separate normally during cell division. Down syndrome, specifically, is caused by a nondisjunction in chromosome 21. As a result, individuals with Down syndrome have a third copy of chromosome 21 in their genome. Hence, Down syndrome is also referred to as trisomy 21. Option E. Hemophilia – This option is incorrect because hemophilia is not caused by an absence or lack of lymphocytes. Hemophilia is a X-linked recessive condition that is caused by mutation to the genes associated with blood clotting. Individuals with hemophilia are unable to form blood clots because they lack blood-clotting proteins, also known as clotting factors.

question.text: Who was responsible for the ecological theory of catastrophism?

explanation.concept_text: Catastrophism is a theory that states that Earth‘s geography and life were shaped by catastrophic events such as natural disasters. Georges Cuvier , a French naturalist that established the theory of catastrophism, believed that populations were shaped by mass extinctions caused by catastrophes. He believed that populations were made up of random organisms that survived catastrophes and populated the area. This theory was at odds with the theory of gradualism. The theory of gradualism suggests that evolution occurs by the gradual accumulation of small changes, rather than rapid, large-scale changes. Since catastrophism is an ecological theory developed by Cuvier, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Hooke – This option is incorrect because Robert Hooke contributed to the development of the cell theory, not the theory of catastrophism. While observing cork under a microscope, Hooke discovered box-like cavities and described them as ”cells”. Hooke’s discovery later led to the development of the cell theory: the theory that every living organism is made up of cells and cells are the smallest structural unit of life. Option B. Darwin – This option is incorrect because Charles Darwin developed the theory of natural selection, not the theory of catastrophism. Natural selection, also called the ”survival of the fittest”, suggests that allele frequencies increase or decrease in order to adapt to the environment. In other words , organisms that are more suited to the given environment will survive and pass down their genes to future generations. Darwin also developed the theory of descent with modification. Descent with modification occurs via natural selection. Darwin thought that over time and generations, traits providing reproductive advantage become more common within a population. Option D. Mendel – This option is incorrect because Gregor Mendel discovered the basic principles of heredity, not the theory of catastrophism. Through extensive experiments with pea plants, Mendel provided the foundations to modern genetics. For example, he discovered that individuals inherit one allele from the male parent and another allele from the female parent, and randomly pass down these alleles to the next generation. Option E. Hardy-Weinberg – This option is incorrect because Hardy and Weinberg developed the basic principles of population genetics, not the theory of catastrophism. The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium describes a state in which allele frequencies remain constant within a population. In order for a population to be in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, the population cannot undergo mutations, natural selection, and gene flow. Furthermore, the population must be large in order to decrease the effects of genetic drift, and demonstrate random mating to decrease the chances of any allele from changing in frequency.

question.text: All of the following processes involve negative feedback EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: Testosterone production following injection of extra testosterone

options.label: C.
options.text: Population levels of a predator and prey species

options.label: D.
options.text: Temperature regulation of the human body

explanation.concept_text: Negative feedback describes the biological response that brings conditions back to their normal or homeostatic state. On the other hand, positive feedback describes an action that intensifies a condition so that it is driven beyond its normal limits. Density-dependent population control is the state in which a population-limiting event becomes more intense as population density increases. Examples include competition for resources, spread of disease, parasites, predation, and toxic effects of waste products. These controls are subject to negative feedback. When a population attains a high density, density-dependent factors cause a decrease in population size, bringing the population density back to “normal”. Density-independent population control is the state in which a population-limiting event occurs independently of the density of the population. Examples include natural disasters or big temperature changes. These events affect populations equally, regardless of the initial size of the populations. In other words, a natural disaster or a drastic temperature change will impact a big population the same way it will impact a smaller population. Since density-independent population control does not involve negative feedback measures that function to bring a population back to its “normal” state – as they are not subject to increased intensity as population size increases, and do not provide a negative feedback to a more stable state but instead affect populations indiscriminately - Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Testosterone production following injection of extra testosterone – This option is incorrect because testosterone production following injection of extra testosterone is an example of negative feedback. The extra testosterone functions to inhibit GnRH production of the hypothalamus, restricting the production of FSH and LH by the anterior pituitary. Since LH is a hormone that stimulates the testes to produce testosterone, the lack of LH will lead to a decrease in testosterone production. Option B. Control of blood calcium levels – This option is incorrect because the control of blood calcium levels is an example of negative feedback. When blood calcium levels decline, the parathyroid gland releases the parathyroid hormone. The parathyroid hormone raises blood calcium levels by stimulating osteoclasts to resorb the bone matrix, causing calcium to be released from the bones. On the other hand, when blood calcium levels increase, the thyroid gland releases calcitonin. Calcitonin decreases blood calcium levels by stimulating osteoblasts to build bone by using up the calcium in the blood. Option C. Population levels of a predator and prey species – This option is incorrect because population levels of a predator and prey species demonstrate negative feedback. Predator and prey populations cycle through time. When predator population increases, they hunt out their prey too effectively and subsequently have no food left. As the predators begin to die off, their prey now have a chance to thrive again, causing an increase in prey population. When prey population becomes too high, the predators have access to an abundant food source and can easily hunt their prey, causing an increase in predator population. Option D. Temperature regulation of the human body – This option is incorrect because the temperature regulation of the human body is an example of negative feedback. The human body uses negative feedback loops to maintain its temperature at a constant level. When body temperature falls, the body tries to retain heat through measures such as shivering and constricting blood vessels. These measures help bring the body temperature back up to normal. When body temperature rises, the body tries to lose its heat to the environment through measures such as sweating and dilating blood vessels. These measures help bring the body temperature back down to normal.

question.text: Which of the following is true regarding the modern cell theory?

options.label: A.
options.text: All cells derive from pre-existing cells created using genetic information stored in the nucleus

options.label: B.
options.text: The cell is the basic unit of structure, function, and organization in all organisms

options.label: C.
options.text: All cells require water for survival

options.label: D.
options.text: All living things are composed of only cells

options.label: E.
options.text: Multicellular organisms are composed of unicellular organisms

correct_answer_text: The cell is the basic unit of structure, function, and organization in all organisms

explanation.concept_text: There are three fundamental theories of biology that you need to understand for your test: the Modern Cell Theory, the RNA World Hypothesis, and the Central Dogma of Genetics. Here are several components of the Modern Cell Theory : Since the Modern Cell Theory states that the cell is the basic unit of structure, function, and organization in all organisms, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. All cells derive from pre-existing cells created using genetic information stored in the nucleus – This option is incorrect because while it is true that all cells derive from pre-existing cells that contain hereditary information, not all cells have a nucleus. In fact, prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles and therefore, do not have a nucleus. Prokaryotic cells, instead, store genetic information in the nucleoid. The nucleoid is an irregular-shaped region within prokaryotic cells that contain all or most of the cell’s genetic material. Option C. All cells require water for survival – This option is incorrect because while water is essential for the survival of the majority of cells, it is not one of the tenants of the modern cell theory. Option D. All living things are composed of only cells – This option is incorrect because while all living organisms are composed of one or more cells, many organisms are also composed of non-living essential components. For example, the adult human body is made up of up to 60% water. Option E. Multicellular organisms are composed of unicellular organisms – This option is incorrect because multicellular organisms are composed of multiple cells, not unicellular organisms. The vast majority, if not all of the cells in a multicellular organism are not unicellular organisms. For example, while the red blood cell is composed of one cell, the red blood cell is not a unicellular organism. Red blood cells exist to assist the metabolic function of the host organism, but the red blood cell itself does not have the characteristics of a fully functional organism. Examples of unicellular organisms include bacteria, protozoa, and some types of algae.

question.text: Failure to produce bile would result in an inability to properly process which of the following substances?

explanation.concept_text: Bile is a dark green to yellowish brown fluid produced by the liver of most vertebrates, that aids in the digestion of lipids in the small intestine. Bile contains a yellow pigment called bilirubin, formed by the breakdown of erythrocytes in the liver. In humans, bile is produced continuously by the liver and is stored in the gall bladder. From here, bile can be sent to the duodenum of the small intestine via the common bile duct. Bile is secreted from the gall bladder in response to a hormone known as cholecystokinin (CCK). CCK is secreted by the small intestine in response to fat digestates. CCK stimulates the gall bladder to release bile and the pancreas to release its digestive enzymes. CCK also decreases the motility of the stomach in order to allow more time for fat digestion. The main purpose of bile is to emulsify the fatty food that is entering the small intestine as chyme. By doing so, the surface area of these fatty foods increases, which effectively enhances the breakdown/hydrolysis of fats via pancreatic lipase within the small intestine. These hydrolyzed fats can then be absorbed and transported wherever it is needed. Furthermore, since bile increases the absorption of fats, it plays an important role in absorbing fat-soluble substances such as vitamins A, D, E, and K. Since the failure to produce bile will lead to a difficulty in breaking down and absorbing fats that enter the digestive system, Option D. Fat is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Protein – This option is incorrect because bile is responsible for the emulsification of fat, not the digestion of protein. Enzymes such as pepsin, trypsin, and chymotrypsin are responsible for the digestion of proteins. Pepsin is secreted by the chief cells of the stomach, initially in the form of pepsinogen. Pepsinogen gets converted into pepsin by the low pH of the stomach. Trypsin and chymotrypsin are secreted by the pancreas into the duodenum of the small intestine, initially in the form of trypsinogen and chymotrypsinogen. These zymogens become activated by an enzyme called enteropeptidase, leading to the digestion of protein. Option B. Trypsin – This option is incorrect because bile is responsible for the emulsification of fat, not the digestion of trypsin. In fact, bile does not have an effect on trypsin. Trypsin is a digestive enzyme that is released by the pancreas as trypsinogen, which gets converted into trypsin by a separate enzyme known as enteropeptidase. Trypsin is responsible for the digestion of proteins. Option C. Glucagon – This option is incorrect because bile is responsible for the emulsification of fat, not the digestion of glucagon. In fact, bile does not have an effect on glucagon. Glucagon is a hormone that is responsible for the maintenance of blood sugar levels. Glucagon is produced by alpha cells of the pancreas and is secreted to increase blood sugar levels by stimulating the liver to convert glycogen into glucose. Glucagon also stimulates gluconeogenesis, the synthesis of glucose, in the liver. Option E. Carbohydrates – This option is incorrect because bile is responsible for the emulsification of fat, not the digestion of carbohydrates. Carbohydrates are broken down by salivary and pancreatic amylase. When food enters the mouth, salivary amylase breaks down starch into maltose by hydrolyzing its glycosidic bonds. The pancreas later secretes pancreatic amylase into the duodenum of the small intestine, which also functions to break down starch into maltose.

question.text: Which of the following involves DNA being used to synthesize RNA?

explanation.concept_text: Transcription serves to create RNA molecules from a DNA template in the nucleus. The process of transcription can be divided into three steps: initiation, elongation, and termination. Initiation is the process in which RNA polymerase attaches to the promoter region of the DNA and unzips the DNA into two strands. A promoter region for transcription often contains a repeating sequence of A (adenine) and T (thymine) nucleotides called the TATA box. Initiation is followed by elongation . Once the DNA is separated into two strands, RNA polymerase continues to unzip DNA and assembles RNA nucleotides using one strand of DNA as a template. Hence, only one strand is transcribed, while the other strand functions to protect against degradation. Lastly, termination occurs when RNA polymerase reaches a special sequence, often a repeated sequence of A (adenine) nucleotides in eukaryotes. Since transcription is the process in which DNA is used to synthesize RNA, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Translation – This option is incorrect because translation is the process in which RNA is used to synthesize polypeptides. Translation begins when a ribosomal subunit attaches to the 5’ end of mRNA, and a tRNA attaches to the start sequence of mRNA (AUG). Once translation is initiated, tRNAs continue to bind to the mRNA sequence, creating a chain of peptide bonds. When the ribosome encounters the stop codon (UAG, UAA, or UGA), the polypeptide and ribosome secrete a release factor that breaks the bond between the tRNA and the final amino acid of the polypeptide. Option C. DNA replication – This option is incorrect because DNA replication is the process in which DNA is copied to produce two identical DNA molecules. DNA is replicated via semiconservative replication. In other words, one of the two strands of DNA is always old (comes from the parent DNA), while the other strand is always new (newly formed during DNA replication). In order to initiate DNA replication, an enzyme called helicase unwinds the double helix. Once the double-stranded DNA is unzipped, an enzyme called DNA polymerase synthesizes the new strand of DNA. Option D. Photosynthesis – This option is incorrect because the process of photosynthesis does not involve DNA nor RNA. Photosynthesis, a process carried out by the chloroplast of plant cells, harnesses light energy in order to synthesize glucose. During the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis, the chlorophyll of chloroplasts absorbs light energy, allowing electrons to be excited and passed onto higher energy levels. This movement of electrons generate ATP and NADPH. During the “dark” reactions of photosynthesis, also known as the Calvin Cycle, the products of the light reaction are utilized and carbon dioxide is fixed to ultimately synthesize glucose. Option E. Meiosis – This option is incorrect because meiosis is a type of cell division that occurs exclusively in gametes. Gametes are haploid male or female germ cells that combine to form a diploid zygote. Meiosis occurs in two steps: meiosis I and meiosis II. Meiosis I involves the separation of homologous chromosomes, whereas meiosis II involves the separation of sister chromatids. While meiosis I produces 2 diploid daughter cells, meiosis II produces 4 haploid daughter cells.

question.text: Which of the following is a feature of a neuron?

explanation.concept_text: The neuron is a highly-specialized, functional unit of the nervous system. Neurons usually consist of several dendrites, a single-branched axon, and a cell body. Dendrites are branched projections at one end of the neuron. They function to receive information from other neurons and transfer it to the cell body. The cell body , also known as the soma, contains the nucleus of the neuron. The cell body is connected to the axon at the axon hillock, where action potentials are generated. The axon transfers impulses away from the cell body, towards the terminal end of the neuron. Aside from these structures, the neuron contains low stores of glycogen and oxygen, and rely on the blood supply for these nutrients. Since dendrites are an essential feature of the neuron that receives information from surrounding neurons, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Medulla – This option is incorrect because the medulla is not a feature of the neuron. The medulla oblongata (commonly abbreviated as just ‘medulla) is a structure at the base of the brain that is responsible for the regulation of breathing, heart rate, and gastrointestinal activity. The term ”medulla” also appears in the excretory system in the context of the adrenal glands. The adrenal medulla is the inner portion of the adrenal gland, located on top of each kidney. The adrenal medulla releases epinephrine and norepinephrine as a part of the ”fight or flight” response. These hormones stimulate the conversion of glycogen to glucose, and increase blood flow to the brain as well as other metabolic activities. Option B. Sphincter – This option is incorrect because sphincters are not a feature of the neuron. Sphincters are ring-shaped muscles that contracts or relaxes to close or open a passage of the body. For example, sphincters are commonly found in the digestive system in order to control the movement of food. After food passes through the mouth and the esophagus, it enters the stomach through the lower esophageal/cardiac sphincter. Once the food gets converted to an acidic mixture called chyme, the chyme enters the small intestine via the pyloric sphincter. Option C. Duodenum – This option is incorrect because the duodenum is not a feature of the neuron. The duodenum is the first portion of the small intestine, responsible for the breakdown of starches and proteins as well as other remaining food types. The majority of digestion occurs in the duodenum. Option D. Sarcoplasm – This option is incorrect because the sarcoplasm is not a feature of the neuron. The sarcoplasm refers to the cytoplasm of striated muscle cells. Similar to the regular cytoplasm, the sarcoplasm contains organelles, ATP, enzymes, and other essential components for metabolic activity.

question.text: Which of the following would be classified as a labile cell?

explanation.concept_text: Labile cells are cells that continuously multiply and divide throughout life. Unlike labile cells, there are inactive cells that rest in the G 0 phase of the cell cycle. It is important to note that these cells are still functional; they are simply not dividing. There are two types of inactive cells: quiescent and senescent. Quiescent cells are cells that temporarily rest in the G 0 phase until they are reactivated to divide again. Senescent cells are cells that are permanently in the G 0 phase because they are either too old or too damaged/degraded to divide. The skin is made up of three layers: epidermis, dermis, and hypodermis. The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin. This layer consists of superficial epithelial tissue that relies on the dermis for oxygen and nutrients. The epidermis is also divided into five layers: stratum corneum, stratum lucidum, stratum granulosum, stratum spinous, and stratum basale. Stratum basale, specifically, is the deepest layer of the skin that contains stem cells that divide to produce epidermal skin cells called keratinocytes. As these keratinocytes rise to the top layer, they accumulate keratin and die by losing their cytoplasm, nucleus, and/or other organelles. Once they reach the outermost layer of the body, they slough off. Since epithelial skin cells constantly die and slough off, it is essential that stem cells of the stratum basale continuously multiply and divide to maintain a sufficient number of epithelial skin cells. Since cells in the epithelium of the skin can be classified as labile cells that undergo steady cell division, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Neurons of the brain – This option is incorrect because neurons of the brain do not continuously multiply and divide throughout life. Once an organism is born, its neurons do not divide and instead live the entire lifespan of the organism. Option B. Skeletal muscles – This option is incorrect because skeletal muscle cells do not continuously multiply and divide throughout life. Skeletal muscle cells divide only until an organism reaches adulthood. Once an organism reaches adulthood, these cells exit the G 1 phase to enter the G 0 phase. The G 0 phase is the “resting“ stage of the cell cycle where the cell is neither dividing nor preparing for cell division. Hence, during adulthood, while skeletal muscle cells can grow in size (hypertrophy), they are unable to grow in number through cell division. Option D. Sinoatrial node of the heart – This option is incorrect because cardiac cells do not continuously multiply and divide throughout life. Cardiac cells divide only until an organism reaches adulthood. Once an organism reaches adulthood, these cells exit the G 1 phase to enter the G 0 phase. The G 0 phase is the “resting“ stage of the cell cycle where the cell is neither dividing nor preparing for cell division. Hence, during adulthood, cardiac cells stop growing in number through cell division. Despite this, cardiac muscles can still grow in size like skeletal muscle cells. Option E. Osteocytes of the bone – This option is incorrect because osteocytes of the bone do not continuously multiply and divide throughout life. They originate from osteoblasts, but eventually become embedded within the bone and lose their ability to go through cell division.

question.text: What would a plant do to counteract excess loss of water?

explanation.concept_text: Stomata are small pores on the epidermis of plant leaves. These pores are controlled by surrounding guard cells . When potassium ions diffuse into guard cells, water moves inwards, causing the cells to expand. Due to the irregular thickness and radial shape of the guard cell, the expansion of these cells causes stomata to open. On the other hand, when potassium ions diffuse out of guard cells, water moves outwards, causing the cells to shrink. Once guard cells shrink, they are no longer able to maintain their shape, causing stomata to close. The opening and closing of stomata affect gas exchange, transpiration, photosynthesis, and many other processes. When stomata are closed, carbon dioxide is not available and the plant cannot photosynthesize. However, when stomata are open, carbon dioxide can enter the leaf for photosynthesis, but the plant risks desiccation from transpiration . Transpiration refers to water loss through evaporation. Hence, in order to prevent an excess loss of water, the opening and closing of stomata are highly controlled. For instance, high temperatures will cause stomata to close, since water evaporates more rapidly under warmer conditions. Since a plant closes its stomata to counteract the excess loss of water through transpiration, Option B. Close stomata is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Less photosynthesis – This option is incorrect because reduced photosynthesis does not counteract the excess loss of water. Photosynthesis is the process in which plants take light energy from the sun to synthesize glucose. While water is used during photosynthesis, a plant only uses a small fraction of its water to carry out the process; the rest is lost through transpiration. Hence, in order to conserve water, it is much more effective to control transpiration, rather than photosynthesis. Furthermore, reduced photosynthesis will eventually cause the plant to perish because plants rely on photosynthesis to produce glucose for energy. Option C. Increase transpiration – This option is incorrect because increased transpiration will lead to the excess loss of water, rather than counteracting it. Transpiration is water loss through evaporation. Hence, if a plant increases its rate of transpiration, an excessive amount of water will leave the plant through its stomata, causing the plant to eventually desiccate. Option D. Inhibit ethylene release – This option is incorrect because ethylene does not have an effect on water loss. Ethylene is a hormone that promotes the ripening of fruit, production of flowers, and leaf abscission/apoptosis. Hence, if ethylene is not produced, the fruit of the plant will take longer to ripen, the flowers will take longer to bloom, and the leaves will take longer to deteriorate and drop. These changes will neither increase nor decrease water loss of the plant. Option E. Decrease root growth – This option is incorrect because while an underdeveloped root will hinder the plant from absorbing a sufficient amount of water from the soil, it will not have an effect on water loss. Plants do not lose water through their roots; they instead lose water through the stomata on their leaves. Hence, changes in root growth will neither increase nor decrease water loss of the plant.

question.text: The weight of newborns in a population was observed over time. Initially, the majority of babies were either very heavy or very light. Over time, the mean of the newborn weight did not change but less heavy and light babies were born. Which form of natural selection took place?

explanation.concept_text: Natural selection is an evolutionary theory that was proposed by Charles Darwin. Natural selection refers to the heritable changes in allele frequency in response to the environment. In essence, favorable alleles are ones that increase the rate of survival and will be selected for within a population. On the other hand, unfavorable alleles are ones that decrease the rate of survival and will be selected against within a population. Individuals with the most “fit” alleles will be able to survive and pass their genes on to their offspring. There are three general types of natural selection: stabilizing selection, directional selection, and disruptive selection. Stabilizing selection is the favoring of intermediate traits. The bell curve favors the intermediate and traits that are at the extremes are selected against. Directional selection is the favoring of traits at one extreme of the range. Traits at the opposite end of the extreme are selected against. Disruptive selection is the favoring of extreme traits, while common or intermediate traits are selected against. A graph of each type of selection is displayed below, with the red curve representing the population distribution before, and the blue curve representing the distribution after the type of selection has taken place. In the scenario in question, the original population consisted of newborns that were very heavy or very light. This represents both ends of the extreme. Over time, we can see that the mean weight of newborns did not change, but less heavy and light babies were being born. In other words, an intermediate weight was becoming more common within the population. Since the intermediate weight is being favored in this scenario and stabilizing selection is the favoring of the intermediate trait, Option E. Stabilizing is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Disruptive – This option is incorrect because disruptive selection occurs when the environment favors extreme or unusual traits, while selecting against common traits. In the scenario in question, the population is favoring intermediate traits (intermediate weight) and selecting against extreme traits (very light or very heavy weights). Option B. Bottleneck – This option is incorrect because the bottleneck effect is not one of the three types of natural selection. A bottleneck effect occurs when there is a drastic decrease in a population, leading to a decrease in the gene pool of that population. The bottleneck effect can occur as a result of a natural disaster, aggressive hunting practices, or the destruction of a population’s habitat. Option C. Directional – This option is incorrect because directional selection occurs when the environment favors traits at one end of the extreme, selecting against intermediate traits or traits at the other end of the extreme. In the scenario in question, the population is favoring intermediate traits (intermediate weight) and selecting against extreme traits (very light or very heavy weights). Option D. Balancing – This option is incorrect because balancing selection refers to the maintenance of alleles within a population which leads to the maintenance of genetic diversity. In the scenario in question, we can see that traits at both ends of the extreme are being selected against, while intermediate traits are being favored. Since the favoring of the intermediate trait is causing a decline in genetic diversity within the population, this scenario does not demonstrate balancing selection.

question.text: Which type of genetic material is made in the nucleolus?

explanation.concept_text: The nucleolus is a dense region contained within the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. The nucleolus plays a crucial role in ribosome biogenesis. Recall that ribosomes are organelles that are responsible for protein translation, which is the conversion of messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. Ribosomes are composed of two ribosomal subunits. These subunits are made from ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and proteins. The ribosomal RNA is produced within the nucleus, and the proteins enter the nucleus via nuclear pores. Once the ribosomal RNA and proteins are in the nucleoplasm, they assemble into their respective ribosomal subunit. Once the subunits are assembled, they exit the nucleus and assemble into functional ribosomes within the cytosol. Since rRNA is produced in the nucleolus, Option C is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. tRNA – This option is incorrect because while transfer RNA (tRNA) is manufactured in the nucleus, it is not synthesized within the nucleolus. tRNA is a type of RNA molecule that is involved in protein translation. tRNA is responsible for bringing amino acids, the monomeric subunit of proteins, to the ribosome so the ribosome can link the amino acids together to make a polypeptide chain. Option B. mRNA – This option is incorrect because while messenger RNA (mRNA) is manufactured in the nucleus, it is not synthesized within the nucleolus. mRNA is synthesized via DNA transcription. DNA transcription is the conversion of DNA into mRNA that is later translated into proteins. Option D. cDNA – This option is incorrect because complementary DNA (cDNA) is not synthesized within the nucleolus. In fact, cDNA can only be produced by certain viruses or by scientists in a molecular biology lab for study. cDNA is made using reverse transcriptase, an enzyme that creates a complementary DNA sequence from a single-stranded RNA template.

question.text: During embryonic development, what develops directly above the notochord?

explanation.concept_text: Neurulation is the embryonic developmental process by which the notochord induces the development of the neural tube from the cells of the ectoderm. Recall that the notochord is derived from the mesoderm, but the neural tube is derived from the ectoderm. The notochord is formed by the cells along the dorsal surface of the mesoderm. While the notochord itself provides support in lower chordates, the vertebrae of higher chordates are formed from nearby cells of the mesoderm. During neurulation, the notochord stimulates cells of the ectoderm to thicken, resulting in the formation of the neural plate . As a part of the ectoderm layer, the neural plate lays directly above the notochord of the mesoderm layer. After the neural plate is developed, this plate will fold and become the neural fold . This fold will continue to fold until it becomes a tube. This tube is known as the neural tube . The neural tube will end up developing into the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord). Since the neural tube develops directly above the notochord, Option E is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Archenteron – This option is incorrect because the archenteron is a structure of the gastrula. The archenteron results from the invagination of the primitive streak during gastrulation. The archenteron is the center cavity of the gastrula that is completely surrounded by endoderm cells, and will eventually develop into the gut tube. Option B. Mesoderm – This option is incorrect because the mesoderm is one of the three embryonic germ layers of the gastrula. The mesoderm is the middle layer of the three. Recall that the notochord is derived from cells of the mesoderm. The notochord induces the development of the spinal cord from cells of the ectoderm which lie directly above the mesoderm. Aside from the notochord, the mesoderm gives rise to the musculoskeletal system, circulatory system, lymphatic system, dermis, and other structures. Option C. Blastocoel – This option is incorrect because the blastocoel is a hollow cavity located inside of the blastula. The blastula is an early embryonic structure consisting of ~128 cells called blastomeres. A blastula has not yet developed into the three embryonic germ layers. Option D. Endoderm – This option is incorrect because the endoderm is the deepest of the three germ layers of the gastrula. The endoderm lies just deep to the mesoderm, the layer that the notochord is derived from. The endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the digestive, respiratory, and urinary tracts; parts of the liver, pancreas, gall bladder, thyroid and parathyroid glands, and thymus.

question.text: Volcanoes are an important part of certain ecosystems. What type of archaea would be found here?

explanation.concept_text: Extremophiles are a group of archaea that live in extreme environments. Thermophiles , specifically, are sulfur-based chemoautotrophs that live in extremely hot places. These organisms are capable of surviving in hot environments due to their membrane composition. Unlike bacteria, archaea can have branched and saturated hydrocarbons that have ether linkages to glycerol groups. This unique membrane composition provides these organisms with thermal stability, but also prevents them from adapting to fluctuating temperatures. Hence, thermophiles may be able to live in hot environments like volcanoes, but would not be able to survive if the surroundings cooled down significantly. Since thermophiles are archaea that are capable of living in extremely hot environments such as volcanoes, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Halophile – This option is incorrect because volcanoes are not inhabited by halophiles. Halophiles are extremophiles that live in environments with high salt concentration. Most halophiles are aerobic and heterotrophic, while others are anaerobic and photosynthetic. Halophiles can be found in environments such as salt lakes and saline soils. For example, halophiles can be found in the Dead Sea, a lake with extremely high salinity. Option C. Aquatic – This option is incorrect because aquatic organisms refer to organisms that live in water for all or most of their lifetime. While there are aquatic extremophiles, volcanoes are not aquatic environments and therefore cannot be inhabited by aquatic extremophiles. Option D. Methanogen – This option is incorrect because volcanoes are not inhabited by methanogens. Methanogens are a group of archaea that produce methane (CH 4 ) as a byproduct of obtaining energy from H 2 to fix CO 2 . These organisms are obligate anaerobes. Methanogens typically live in swamps and marshes, but can also be found in dead and decaying matter.

question.text: Which of the following structures is the pacemaker of the heart?

explanation.concept_text: The sinoatrial (SA) node is the pacemaker of the heart. The sinoatrial node is located within the upper wall of the right atrium and regulates the rate at which the heart beats. The SA node is a group of specialized cardiac muscle cells that initiates by contracting both atria. The contraction of the atria sends blood into both ventricles. The electrical impulse originating from the SA node is transferred to the atrioventricular node (AV node) located on the floor of the right atrium. The AV node will add a delay before sending the impulse to the next structure, the bundle of His . The purpose of this brief delay is to ensure that the ventricles and the atria do not contract at the same time. It is important to allow all the blood from the atria to empty into the ventricles before ventricular contraction. Once the impulse has reached the bundle of His, which is located in the interventricular septum, the impulse will be directed to the Purkinje fibers, which are found in the walls of each ventricle. Once the impulse has reached the Purkinje fibers, the ventricles will contract. Since the sinoatrial node is the pacemaker of the heart and regulates the rate at which the heart beats, Option D is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Interventricular septum – This option is incorrect because the interventricular septum is simply a wall of tissue that separates the left and right ventricles which contain the oxygenated blood and deoxygenated blood respectively. The interventricular septum is not the pacemaker of the heart. Option B. Purkinje fibers – This option is incorrect because the Purkinje fibers transmit a nervous signal from the bundle of His, which is located in the interventricular septum, to the ventricles. This ensures a simultaneous, coordinated contraction of the left and right ventricles. The Purkinje fibers are not the pacemaker of the heart. Option C. Sympathetic nerves – This option is incorrect because sympathetic nerves are responsible for innervating the sinoatrial (SA) node when the sympathetic nervous system is activated. Recall that the sympathetic nervous system is responsible for the “fight or flight” response and will increase heart rate. The sympathetic nerves are not the pacemaker of the heart. Aside from increasing heart rate, sympathetic nerves also increase blood pressure and the generation of energy. Sympathetic nerves, on the other hand, inhibit digestion, urination, and salivary secretion. Option E. Atrioventricular node – This option is incorrect because the atrioventricular (AV) node is not the pacemaker of the heart. The AV node is located on the floor of the right atrium. After the sinoatrial node has initiated contraction of the atria, the electrical impulse is sent to the AV node. The AV node will add a brief delay before sending the impulse to the bundle of His. This brief delay is to ensure that the ventricles and the atria do not contract simultaneously.

question.text: The following graph represents four species all occupying a similar ecosystem. Based on the graph, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A.
options.text: Several of the species demonstrate a mutualistic relationship

options.label: B.
options.text: None of the species increased in population size overall

options.label: C.
options.text: Two of the species occupy the same niche

options.label: D.
options.text: Temperature was the limiting factor for growth

options.label: E.
options.text: All species share a common ancestor

correct_answer_text: Two of the species occupy the same niche

explanation.concept_text: In the given graph, we can observe that the rabbit population (expressed in red) declines as the deer population (expressed in blue) increases. Through this, we can deduce that rabbits and foxes exhibit a type of interspecific competition. Interspecific competition refers to the interactions between members of different species. Since the members are competing against each other for the same resources, interspecific competition becomes necessary if access to the resource is limited. In this case, we can predict that the deer population grew in size because it had better access to the shared resource. On the other hand, the rabbit population shrunk in size because the deer depleted them of the shared resource. This shared resource can also be described as a niche. A niche includes all the biotic and abiotic resources in the environment used by an organism. When an organism is said to “occupy” a niche, certain resources are consumed or certain qualities of the environment are changed by the presence of the organism. No two species can occupy the same niche indefinitely because all resources are finite. Since the deer and rabbits are most likely exhibiting interspecific competition by occupying the same niche, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Several of the species demonstrate a mutualistic relationship – This option is incorrect because none of the species exhibit a mutualistic relationship. Mutualism is a type of symbiosis in which the relationship is beneficial to both species. Since a mutualistic relationship benefits both species involved, the populations of both species must be increasing. However, there are no pairs of species on the given graph that are growing in population size together. Option B. None of the species increased in population size overall – This option is incorrect because the deer population (expressed in blue) is demonstrating a significant increase in overall population size. Option D. Temperature was the limiting factor for growth – This option is incorrect because while temperature could have been a limiting factor for growth, it is impossible to come to such conclusion based on the given graph. The graph does not indicate the temperature of the environment and whether the species were affected by it. We would need additional information about the species and their environment in order to come to a conclusion on the limiting factors of growth. Option E . All species share a common ancestor – This option is incorrect because while the species could share a common ancestor, it is impossible to come to such conclusion based on the given graph. The graph does not indicate ancestry of the species. We would need additional information about ancestry through a phylogenetic tree or cladogram.

question.text: The pancreas releases enzymes used in digestion. Which of the following pancreatic enzymes is used to cleave peptide chains?

explanation.concept_text: Recall that peptide bonds are the bonds that link adjacent amino acids together to create long polypeptide chains (proteins). There are a couple of enzymes that the pancreas secretes to cleave these peptide bonds for digestion and absorption by the body. These two enzymes are known as chymotrypsin and trypsin. Chymotrypsin and trypsin are both secreted from the pancreas as zymogens. Zymogens are the inactive precursor of an enzyme. Chymotrypsin gets secreted as chymotrypsinogen and trypsin gets secreted as trypsinogen. As chyme (a mixture of food and acidic gastric juice) enters the small intestine, cells of the small intestine will secrete cholecystokinin, a hormone that, among other functions, will signal the pancreas to release its digestive enzymes. Chymotrypsinogen and trypsinogen are secreted from the pancreas and converted into chymotrypsin and trypsin via enteropeptidase , which is an enzyme released from glands of the small intestine in response to the entrance of chyme. Because chymotrypsin is the only answer choice that represents a pancreatic enzyme used to cleave peptide bonds, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Nuclease – This option is incorrect because nucleases are enzymes that cleave phosphodiester bonds that are found within DNA and RNA. While nucleases are released from the pancreas, they do not cleave peptide bonds found within proteins. Option C. Amylase – This option is incorrect because while amylases are enzymes released by both the salivary glands in the mouth and by the pancreas, amylases are responsible for the breakdown of carbohydrates. Pancreatic amylase does not cleave the peptide bonds found within proteins. Option D. Pepsin – This option is incorrect because pepsin is secreted from the chief cells of the stomach, not the pancreas. Pepsin is secreted as pepsinogen and converted into pepsin, when in the presence of stomach acid. While pepsin does cleave peptide bonds found within proteins, pepsin is not secreted from the pancreas. Option E. Maltose – This option is incorrect because maltose is not an enzyme. Maltose is a disaccharide which is formed from the joining of two glucose monomers via an alpha-1,4-glycosidic bond.
